PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATHS OF FORMER SENATORS JOHN THOMAS KANE AND MERVYN GEORGE EVERETT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the deaths on 27 October 1988 of former Senator John Thomas Kane, senator for New South Wales from 1970 to 1974, and the Hon. Mervyn George Everett, QC, senator for Tasmania from 1974 to 1975.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the deaths on 27 October 1988 of John Thomas Kane, a Senator for the State of New South Wales from 1970 to 1974, and the Hon. Mervyn George Everett, QC, a Senator for the State of Tasmania from 1974 to 1975, places on record its appreciation of their meritorious public service and tenders its sympathy to their families in their bereavement.

I intend to be quite brief in my remarks about this matter. Senator Kane was not known to me personally. He was a senator from the State of New South Wales for four years as a member of the Democratic Labor Party and he had had a long and prominent career, in the earlier part of his life, in the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in New South Wales. On behalf of the Labor Party, I extend to his family our regrets at his passing.

Former Senator Everett was known to me personally and I want to say one or two things. Mervyn Everett was born on 7 October 1917 at Hobart, Tasmania. Prior to entering Federal Parliament, he was elected in 1964 to the seat of Denison in the Tasmanian House of Assembly and he held that seat until his resignation in April 1974. Mr Everett served Tasmania as Minister for Health from 1964 to 1969, and as Deputy Premier, Attorney-General, Minister for the Environment, and Minister Administering the Racing and Gaming Act from 1972 to 1974. He was elected to the Senate in 1974. He served on various parliamentary committees, including the Senate Standing Committee on Privileges, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which he was Chairman, and the Senate Select Committee on Foreign Ownership and Control.

I had the privilege, indeed the pleasure, of serving on some of those committees with Senator Everett, particularly the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. As I recall it, Senator Chaney was a member of the Committee for some of that time and Senator Peter Baume was also a member of the Committee. I think at various times Senator Chaney and I were both on the Privileges and Regulations and Ordinances committees with the then Senator Everett. In his chairmanship of those committees he displayed not only a profound legal knowledge-Mervyn Everett was a very fine lawyer-but also an incredible degree of fairness. He was a very fair and sensible chairman and he guided the committees in a way of which any Senate could be proud in terms of the work they had to do at that time. He was also a very regular contributor to debate in this chamber; he always made good contributions.

It is one of those little things of history one recalls: On 11 November 1975 Senator Everett was in this chamber at about 2 o'clock in the afternoon. I had just been told that the Government had been dismissed and I came in and told him. I think that he was on his own in the chamber. He made some remark like, `Anything's possible'. I do not recall exactly what it was, but I remember that incident very clearly.

Mervyn Everett was an eminent jurist. He was a law lecturer. He was appointed a Queen's Counsel in 1965 and served both as a Supreme Court judge and a justice of the Federal Court. While attending a legal conference in Singapore on the implications of the Nuremberg trials, he was taken ill and died suddenly. I think that at that time he was preparing a PhD thesis on that topic. As I have suggested earlier, he was a loyal and tireless worker for his Party-the Labor Party-and a respected member of the Senate. He was President of the Tasmanian branch of the ALP from 1973 to 1974, something which is always an onerous task. I have no doubt that he discharged it with great skill. He also served his country as a member of the Australian Imperial Force for four years.

I was privileged enough to be able to number Merv Everett amongst my closer friends in this place. I regard him as having led a very dedicated and fine life in law and politics. I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in its bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I support the motion of condolence which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Both Mr Kane and Mr Everett were in the Senate for relatively short periods-Mr Kane from 1970 to 1974 and Mr Everett from 1974 to 1975. Each, in a very different way, made a very significant contribution both to the Senate and to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not know former Senator Kane. He left the Senate in the election in which both Senator Button and I were elected to this place. He, along with the other Democratic Labor Party (DLP) senators, lost his seat. I think that that was the last representation that they had in this Parliament. Therefore, I am unable to speak of him personally, but I was struck by the description of him that was given by Mr B. A. Santamaria in the Australian newspaper today. I think that it would be a fairer representation of him to use Mr Santamaria's words than to use my own. Mr Santamaria made the point in this morning's Australian that there were a number of qualities of Mr Kane which were of note. Referring to both Mr Kane and the late Harry Hurrell, he said:

No two people more clearly manifested the fundamental philosophical values of the industrial movement which, during the 1940s and '50s, defeated the communist drive to take over the Australian trade unions and the Labor Party.
Later he said:

Kane and Hurrell were Labor men, born and bred. Both the circumstances of their origins and the hardships of their earliest years had implanted in them a strong instinct for social justice in its original connotation.

Senator Kane was a manual worker and the offspring of generations of manual workers who had never had the advantage of a secondary, let alone tertiary, education. As Mr Santamaria pointed out, Mr Kane and men like him were to prove that dedication to a cause, accompanied by unremitting work, based on a set of firmly held moral principles, could accomplish much more than mere education endowment when it rests on nothing more solid than today's shifting sands of moral relativism. Mr Santamaria continued:

Jack Kane began his working life as a miner in Lithgow, the early death of his father forcing him to become the family's breadwinner-at 12 shillings and sixpence a week. Thrown out of work in the Depression, he kept his family together by selling fruit and vegetables door to door.

Kane's industrial abilities had been noted by the Communist Party leadership during his mining days in Lithgow, and he was invited to join its Militant Minority Movement. But despite the economic devastation of the Depression providing plenty of justification, his religious faith and democratic instincts made him refuse the tempting offer of guaranteed future union leadership in the communist interest.

He became a member of the NSW Transport Workers Union, opposing the existing union leadership after viewing the corruption which flourished at that time, and paid the penalty with threats being made against him and his family.

When the ``Movement'' was formed to fight communism in the mid-'40s, Jack Kane joined. He went on to join the ALP Industrial Group Movement, becoming its NSW secretary and, later, organising secretary and acting State secretary of the ALP. He was sacked when gross betrayal led to the victory of the Evattite forces over the NSW State executive in 1955-56. The NSW Democratic Labor Party, which he founded, joined with the Victorian ALP to establish a nationwide DLP, of which he became federal secretary. Later, as a senator for NSW, Kane was to distinguish himself among the impressive company of the five DLP senators.

When, after the tragic ``Gair Affair'', the DLP was eliminated as a parliamentary force, Kane continued to work for the same ideals as had animated the previous 30 years of his life as federal vice-president of the National Civic Council (NCC).
Although terminally ill, Kane attended a meeting of the NSW State executive of the NCC on the Saturday before his death. It can be truthfully said that he never gave up.

I have used the words of Mr Santamaria not because they would be universally agreed with in this chamber, but because I think they reflect one of his distinguished contemporary's views of his life, views which I substantially share. Mr Kane was part of one of the great dramas of Australian politics in the mid-1950s. I think that all honourable senators would agree that the breaches within the Australian Labour Party (ALP) at that time were based on very strongly differing principles and views about principles. Senator Kane and the other DLP Senators were outraged by the Gair appointment to an ambassadorship by the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, and ultimately they all lost their seats in the Parliament, having threatened Supply in 1974. Mr Kane, obviously, made a very distinguished, vigorous and important contribution during those years. On behalf of the Opposition, I extend our sympathy to his family.

The late Mervyn George Everett was elected to Parliament at the same election as Senator Button and I were. He chose to leave, as I recall, at the following election. I think he found that there were other areas in which his very considerable talents could be put to better use. I echo many of the things which were said by Senator Button. I had the great pleasure of serving with him on a number of committees such as the Select Committee on Foreign Ownership and Control and, more importantly, on the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of which he was chairman from February 1975.

For those people who believe that Parliament has a greater role, Senator Everett's role during the last year of the Whitlam Government was a very distinguished one indeed. Those honourable senators who were here at the time will remember the commitment of the Whitlam Government to the national compensation scheme and the examination of that proposal by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee under the chairmanship of Mervyn Everett.

I must say that as a very new senator I was extremely concerned at the outcome of that inquiry because it seemed to me that the evidence pointed to the need for very considerable change to that proposal. As the inquiry continued under the chairmanship of Senator Everett, I was extremely impressed by his objectivity and fairness-I think `fairness' was the expression used by Senator Button-and I do not think anybody could say that the evidence which was put before that Committee was not very carefully presented in the Committee's report. Of course, the Committee reported in terms that the legislation should be withdrawn and redrafted. That took a fair amount of political courage, as Senator Button will remember, from the upbraiding that I recall his receiving in a very public way from the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. During that inquiry I was deeply impressed by the legal skills of Senator Everett. They were of the highest order. He had, in addition to the qualities which have been mentioned by Senator Button, very great qualities as a draftsman. He wrote beautifully, and that is unusual. That is the only point which I would make in addition to those very complimentary remarks which have been made by Senator Button.

I had a bit to do with the Everett family. As one saw from time to time both in his political role and later in his Inter-State Commission role, like many people in this place he had a family with split political affiliations. His daughter was a very active member of the Tasmanian Young Liberals. During that period I saw her, and I remember thinking that they had a great deal in common but that there were many things which they did not share. On behalf of the Opposition I extend our sympathy to the late Mr Everett's family in the loss of a very distinguished and fine Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither I nor any of my colleagues knew Senators Kane and Everett, since they served in the Senate before any of us came to this chamber. I did, however, know Senator Kane by reputation. I think probably most people who followed the events of the split in the Australian Labor Party knew his name well. Senator Everett's name as a distinguished parliamentarian in Tasmania was well known even though, unfortunately, it is sometimes more difficult to get news between the Australian States than between our country and overseas countries. The political career of Mr Everett used to turn up in the Queensland newspapers from time to time. He was certainly a figure, even when in the State Parliament, who had a national standing. It is not possible to make any comments with regard to any knowledge that we had of them personally. I would therefore just like to associate my colleagues with the motion moved by Senator Button and extend our condolences to the families of Senator Kane and Senator Everett.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Tasmanian Labor senator, I thought it appropriate to participate in support of this motion of condolence for Mervyn Everett, whose sudden death came as a shock to me a few days ago. I had known Merv Everett since I first became involved in the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania in the late 1960s. He was one of the Labor members of the House of Assembly for Denison. He had been Minister for Health in previous Labor governments and was Attorney-General in the State Labor Government which returned to office in Tasmania early in 1972. One of the things from that period for which I remember him was his courageous decision to give his Attorney-General's fiat which allowed a conservation movement court case to go ahead in connection with the flooding of Lake Pedder, his action being contrary to the obvious preference of the Cabinet of which he was a member at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: He was particularly helpful and supportive of me during my term as the member for Denison in the House of Representatives from 1972 to 1975 and I was greatly appreciative of that. When the 1974 Federal double dissolution election arose suddenly, Merv Everett made a sudden decision to resign from the State Parliament and seek endorsement on the Party's ticket for the Senate. He thereby became a member of the Senate for the following 18 months, coming in with Don Grimes, who had already been endorsed as a candidate for the half-Senate election which had been expected.

Senator Chaney referred to this matter. Merv and Don, plus John Button, were amongst those who earned the ire of Gough Whitlam late in 1975 because of the Senate committee report they presented which did not wholeheartedly endorse the then proposed national compensation scheme. The phase `bloody doctors and lawyers' is one I well remember coming from the then Prime Minister. While it was a bit of a come-down for a senior State Minister to find himself as a backbencher here, I think Merv Everett quite enjoyed his period in the Senate although, of course, he experienced the frustration of being a member of the Caucus at that time which we all shared.

His Senate career was cut short, as was my House of Representatives career, by the 1975 double dissolution. While we had won five Senate seats in 1974, we could manage only four in 1975. Merv Everett had volunteered to run at No. 5 after Don Grimes, who was placed at No. 4, in the hope of that being of assistance to the Party. Although he missed out on keeping his seat, at one stage of the count it looked as though he would be elected from the No. 5 position at the expense of Don Grimes. I think Don Grimes had virtually conceded that he had lost his seat. However, that did not happen and he, of course, went on to become a respected Minister in this Government. I think I can speak for Don Grimes, who is now our Ambassador to the Netherlands, in saying that he would be more upset than most to hear of the loss of Merv Everett.

Mr Everett then returned to the bar, to the State Supreme Court, then to the Federal Court of Australia and the Presidency of the Inter-State Commission where he did some very valuable and solid work. It was from this position that he retired not so long ago. In recent years I saw him mainly on aeroplanes and in airport lounges. He was always keen to have interesting and informative conversations about current events and the state of the world. I will always value those chats and the wisdom he imparted. As is clear to everyone, Merv Everett had a varied career of real public service for which Tasmania and the nation are grateful. He maintained his loyalty to and interest in the Australian Labor Party. I pass on my condolences to his widow, Daphne. I again express my thanks and those of the Tasmanian Branch of the ALP for Mervyn George Everett's distinguished life and friendship.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish very briefly as a Liberal senator for Tasmania to pay tribute to the contribution of an Australian Labor Party senator from my State. He was one of those rare individuals who, no matter what he did in his public life, made a contribution to his State in such a varied field, as so many before me have said. I found him a man with an intriguing mind, with great capacity for intellectual thought. He was recognised as a fine lawyer. In fact, it was as Attorney-General that I knew him. He had the perspicacity to offer me a job. However, within a week or so he changed his mind and came to Canberra instead-so the job was not there either. I would also like to remember him for the final job he did for my State and that was as Chairman of the Inter-State Commission, where he reviewed in detail the worth of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme. All Tasmanians owe him a debt for having put that firmly on the record as being of great and lasting importance to Tasmania. This Government has now accepted that the scheme must be continued as those on this side of the chamber have always believed. I mourn his passing and I also add my condolences to those expressed to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate myself with the condolence motion for Merv Everett and Jack Kane; I knew them both. Merv Everett served in the State Parliament for 10 years prior to coming to the Federal Parliament. He was Minister for Health for about five or six of those years. The portfolio was not without controversy, amongst which was the issue of fluoride.

SPEECH.PARA: I knew Merv in the Australian Labor Party when consideration was being given in 1975 to the possibility of a double dissolution. I was on the State Executive of the Labor Party. Merv Everett volunteered to drop down to the No. 5 position when he could have received the second or third position. It was rather ironical that subsequently I was expelled from the Labor Party and I then stood for the Senate. I suppose it could have been said that I could have taken Merv Everett's position although it could equally have been said that I could have taken a position from the other side. Nevertheless, I do not know whether Merv, having been in State Cabinet for almost 10 years and having served as a chairman of a committee of a government of which he was a member, would have taken it easily sitting on the back bench under a new administration. I recall that another senator, Jim McClelland, did not find that experience very easy or very enlightening. He continued to say so then, and probably continues to say so now.

Merv Everett was a Queen's Counsel. He went on to become a judge of the Supreme Court of Tasmania. As has been said, he served as President of the Inter State Commission. He did some very interesting work on the implications of the Nuremberg trials. There are many of us who are interested in the implications of the Nuremberg trials, particularly as they relate to the issue of experiments on humans. I will be one who will be very interested to read of Merv Everett's studies in that sphere.

On Thursday I heard of Merv's death from a member of the police force who was visibly upset at his death. That person had had his battles and, I am sure, Merv Everett was one who understood those and acted so that justice was eventually achieved. My sympathy is extended to his family.

I also knew Jack Kane. The history of his contribution in the political sphere has been detailed by Senator Chaney and by Senator Button. I do not want to go over those details. Jack Kane was well known by the press gallery both before and after he became a senator. Members of the press gallery invariably described him in a respectful way as being politically seasoned and shrewd. For example, Max Walsh commented in one article in 1972:
Even Senator Jack Kane's political opponents, of which he has host, concede that the DLP Senator is one of the country's craftiest politicians . . .

That might have been so. He was in fact regarded as a very good political organiser. He had the ability to organise and marshal the talents of other people. For example, in the 1950s he succeeded in getting the late Professor James McAuley to prepare drafts, statements and manifestos. His election to the Senate was regarded as a bit of a fluke because he benefited unexpectedly from the flow of Australian Labor Party preferences. However, had there been a succession of double dissolutions, as we have experienced since that time, he would have been in the Senate much earlier than 1970.

He was a battler. His maiden speech was largely devoted to the inadequacy of the income on which retirees and pensioners had to struggle. I do not think this occurs nowadays but his maiden speech was delivered in support of an urgency motion which he had moved.

Jack Kane did in fact devote his life to uplifting the downtrodden and to cham- pioning the causes of the underprivileged. He was part of the movement to bring about a greater measure of social justice within the overall framework of Christian social principles. Of course, he was opposed very strongly to the communist and left wing influence in Australia, particularly in the trade union movement. Over the decades many aspiring trade union candidates benefited from his advice and knowledge. Some of them went on to win positions of influence in important trade unions and brought them within the fold of the Labor Party. Jack Kane, however, was essentially a humble person who never sought any personal limelight unless it was useful to the cause in which he was involved. He made no claim to being highly educated, but was a good platform orator in the Labor style of the 1940s and 1950s. He would deliver a sharp attack, but not a malicious attack.

I am inclined to think that one of the significant events for which Jack Kane will be remembered is the Burchett case, when Wilfred Burchett sued him over an article in November 1971 which alleged that Wilfred Burchett had been associated with the KGB and had taken statements from Australian prisoners of war during the Korean conflict. Wilfred Burchett finally lost the case in 1974 when a 12-man jury found that while the article might have been defamatory of Burchett, it was a fair report of Senate proceedings. The jury was not required to make any finding about the truth of the material. Jack Kane and Wilfred Burchett were not really two individuals ranged against each other in court: it was a conflict between two dia- metrically opposed causes.

Jack Kane was buried in Botany cemetery yesterday, after a concelebrated requiem mass in St Thomas More's Catholic Church. I cannot think of any more aptly named church in which a requiem mass should be held for a person such as the late Jack Kane. Sir Thomas More stood for principles in public life, and so did Jack Kane. To his wife, Rose, their children, John and Pat, and their families, their late son Bob's family, to Jack's brother Charlie and to all his relatives and friends, I offer my sincere condolence at his parting.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern at the possibility that future significant employment opportunities in Canberra may be lost if a Casino is not included in the Section 19 development proposed for Civic.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should strongly support the inclusion of a Casino in the Section 19 development.
The Casino is a critical element in this project for maximising the economic development of Canberra.

It will generate significant employment in the building industry and assist in stabilising the industry in the future as well as providing long term permanent employment in the hospitality and other related industries. The Section 19 development is not viable without a Casino.
We therefore call on you to give the A.C.T. Casino Control Ordinance, and through it the total Section 19 development, your full and immediate support.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators McMullan (from 406 citizens) and Reid (from 730 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

Note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification

Call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, cesium 137, cesium 134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

We request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ban the importation of any radioactive substances, or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation; disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country; ban the irradiation of food in this country; and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.

We ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, request the Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, shall ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. One in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cook (from 700 citizens) and Jones (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia
Respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and the honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth:
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall the millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned stresses the urgency of the need for the proposed development at Section 19 City to proceed, with a casino included. The casino is critical to the viability of the project.

The private sector in the ACT has consistently supported efforts to diversify the economic and employment bases in the Territory, aiming to increase private sector employment and reduce reliance on Government employment. All Governments have supported the need for this action.

The Civic Square Entertainment Centre is a vital step in the process. It will not only cushion the effect of the current, and sharp, downturn in the construction industry, but will provide an additional 1,400 permanent jobs when it begins operation. It will provide over 500 jobs during the construction period.

A McNair Anderson survey commissioned by the private sector found the Canberra Community to be 2:1 in favour of a casino. A Social Impact Study for the Government could not see why the development, with a properly controlled casino, should not proceed. We believe it was a properly based enquiry with well-reasoned findings.
We categorically reject any proposition that the Entertainment Centre will be viable without the Casino, unless there is substantial government funding. We do not want that funding.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should support the ACT Casino Control Ordinance, thus allowing the total development to proceed and strengthening the role of the private sector in the National Capital.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Reid (from 15 representatives of Australian Capital Territory organisations).

PETITION.TITLE: Canberra-Batemans Bay Road: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
Grave concern with the insufficient level of Government grants provided for carrying out improvements to the Canberra/Batemans Bay (MR51) Road.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Senate will call upon the government to take whatever steps are necessary to allow for and provide special substantial direct funding to carry out the necessary improvements to the road and, further, call upon the New South Wales State Government to accept greater financial responsibility for the upgrading and maintenance of the said road.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chlorofluorocarbons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate in Parliament:
The extreme concern about the depletion of the ozone in the atmosphere, and in its imminent effect on ourselves, our families and our future.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Evans and Senator Cook are absent from the chamber for Question Time today, as they are attending the Papua New Guinea-Australia inaugural Ministerial Council meeting in Port Moresby. Any questions in this chamber on foreign affairs matters should be directed to me. Those relating to the portfolio of transport and communications should be directed to Senator Robert Ray. Questions relating to Senator Cook's portfolio or those he represents in this chamber should be directed to Senator Walsh.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. What provisions has the Government included in its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill to prevent abuses of the use of public moneys by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission similar to those which have been identified by Senate Estimates Committee E?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an assumption made in the question about the scope and the type of abuses said to have been revealed in the deliberations of Estimates Committee E last week and the week before, as it examined the estimates for the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. Indeed, it is fair to say that, while many-amounting to probably hundreds but certainly dozens-allegations were made of maladministration and corruption and a general smear about a black mafia operating throughout the distribution of funds by both departmental and Commission personnel, very few actually came to the point where substance could be fleshed out in relation to those allegations. There were many instances in the course of the hearings when the questioning fell quite flat, as I think would be acknowledged even by those who put the questions.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as allegations have been made which suggest either incompetence or a lack of proper procedures in relation to the provision of funds for various projects, it is quite clear that the Government is as concerned as any senator, any parliamentarian or indeed any citizen of Australia, including Aboriginal citizens of Australia, is when serious instances are alleged of misuse of funds contributed by taxpayers to advance in this case the cause of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

For that reason the Government has taken very swift steps to further identify the sorts of matters which emerged as of concern and to remedy the situation. Indeed, so far as mismanagement has been alleged, the particular steps taken by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and concurred in and indeed announced by or certainly given publicity by the Prime Minister yesterday, indicate the vigour and the resolve with which this Government will attack any suggestions of maladministration in any portfolio, but particularly in relation to the allegations that have been made.

As honourable senators will know, the Auditor-General has been asked to provide special assistance in relation to an examination of the financial management of relevant Aboriginal programs within the ADC. Indeed, the Minister for Finance has also been approached by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for expert advice and assistance. I believe that the provision of that special skilled advice, which is of course additional to the constant audit to which the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is properly and normally subject, will reveal any areas of weakness that have to be dealt with and will thus provide a very firm foundation for the sorts of controls and management practices which will be required in years to come under the new administration of moneys in relation to Aboriginal affairs programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Whilst thanking the Minister for his answer, I put it to him that he in no way addressed the question I posed to him, which was: What provisions has the Government included in its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill to prevent abuses of the use of public moneys similar to those identified and alleged last week? Am I to take it from the comment at the end of his answer-or his non-answer-to that question that the Government will be moving amendments before the Bill, which I understand is to be voted on in a couple of weeks, is put to a vote? Can he tell the Senate now specifically what provisions are in the Bill to meet the points I have raised?

—I am simply saying that this Government has expressed its resolve to deal with any allegations relating to maladministration and mismanagement in the disbursement of moneys contributed by the people of Australia to any program. Whether it is in relation to current programs being administered under the current arrangements within the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio or whether it is in relation to programs under the new structure that will be established, that resolve will be apparent and I believe will be effective.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer provide any statistical evidence to support his comments last Friday that house prices in the current housing boom are no higher as a proportion of average weekly earnings than they were in previous housing booms? Has the Minister received any confirmation from the housing industry that house prices will in fact fall in real terms in the next 12 months?
—Can the Minister find anybody in Australia who believes him?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If people have any sense they will.
—Senator Puplick is stuck in here while his opponent is out making phone calls.

—Speaking of that: I would like to thank the anonymous Liberal Party senator who sent to me through the internal mail, in a Senate envelope marked confidential, the `Stay in Touch' column's account of the Liberal Party preselection struggle. Whoever it was, I would like to thank him or her. We had noticed it already but I am always grateful to receive--
—Order! It is hardly relevant to the question, Senator Walsh.

—You are absolutely right, Mr President. The peak of the last housing boom was in 1981, specifically in the September quarter. That is shown by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) index, not the Housing Industry Association (HIA) and Commonwealth Bank of Australia index, which is based on the median price of houses sold and can be quite misleading. The ABS index, based on actual prices from 1981 adjusted by subsequent movements in the consumer price index, shows that housing prices peaked in the September quarter at 1.030. They subsequently bottomed at 0.885-that is, 14 or 15 per cent lower-in the first quarter of 1987. They are presently below the 1981 peak. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that table which shows the quarterly movements throughout a period of eight years.

ANSWER.PARA: Source: Consumer Price Index, ABS Cat. No. 6401.0

TALK.START.PARA: —The peak prices of September 1981 were unsustainable and they fell. I have no doubt that they will fall again, at least in real terms and possibly even in nominal terms-not the other way around, as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) misreported on the AM program yesterday morning, just as it misreported a couple of other things on the same program. It makes one wonder sometimes why $450m of taxpayers' money is spent in spreading misinformation around the community. In regard to the Housing Industry Association, Dr Silberberg was asked on that AM program to which I referred-since it was a direct voice recording, I presume the ABC got it right-about my prediction that housing prices would fall some time in the not too distant future, at least in real terms. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Well there will be regional variations, we would believe, and in those markets which have exhibited the fastest growth over the past year-and that's mainly Sydney-you would have to expect that house prices would come off.
When asked what he meant by `come off', he said:
Plateau, and really there is not, on this occasion, a significant difference between HIA and Senator Walsh.

I am pleased to hear that from the HIA because all speculative booms have the potential to damage both individuals and the macro-economy. The speculative boom, or the big bull run, on the stock exchange in 1987 ultimately did a lot of damage to individuals. It has not done as much damage to the economy as some people expected at the time, but speculative booms of this type are not desirable from either a whole society or an individual perspective. The less frequently they happen and the less intense they are on the odd occasion when they do happen, the better.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and is supplementary to that which was asked by Senator Short. I remind the Minister of the question which was actually asked by Senator Short:

QUESTION.PARA: What provisions has the Government included in its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill to prevent similar abuses of the use of public moneys by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission . . .

The Minister replied to both the question and the supplementary question in terms of the Government's resolve to tackle abuses, and I acknowledge that as the Minister's claim. I remind the Minister that what is being asked of him is what are the provisions, if any, in this legislation which will not tackle abuses but prevent abuses? Can the Minister identify whether there are any provisions of that sort which aim to resolve the difficulties which have been identified in the past by the former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, quite apart from the recent Senate Estimates Committee inquiry? I further ask the Minister, in the light of his comments about the advice that has been received from the Department of Finance, whether he is saying that the Government is looking to learn from that Department what protective provisions might be included in the legislation which would reduce the possibility of a similar waste of taxpayers' funds of the sort that we have seen identified in the last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to point out that, whatever the new structure turns out to be, it will be subject to the Commonwealth auditing provisions that normally apply. I believe that the sorts of lessons we may learn from the Australian Audit Office's special reference to look at the Aboriginal Development Commission, as requested by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and the special assistance offered in response to a letter from Mr Hand to the Minister for Finance by the provision of advice at a senior level, will reveal those steps that need to be taken to ensure that money spent in the furtherance of the development of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is not only wisely spent, in some sort of political assessment, but properly spent in a way which reflects good management supervision and control of the disbursement of what are very large sums of money. It is in that respect that I believe the new structure will benefit from the special supervision or special inquiry that is being undertaken. In that sense, the lessons learned will no doubt be of value to the new management structure that will have to emerge.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I note that the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) held the first ever Manufacturing Outlook Conference in Melbourne last week. What views were expressed at the conference about the future of manufacturing industry in Australia? Did the views expressed give some optimism for growth in manufacturing exports as a means of overcoming the balance of payments contraint?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Bureau of Industry Economics did hold the first Manufacturing Outlook Conference in Melbourne last week. Such outlook conferences have had a long tradition in the agricultural sector, and I am hopeful that last week's conference will be the start of an equally important tradition in manufacturing. The conference attracted as speakers some of Australia's foremost corporate decision makers. I think it is fair to say there was general recognition of the wide range of investment opportunities in the manufacturing sector. Speakers at the conference from various sectors of industry referred to the strong growth in manufacturing investment and exports in recent years. With continued growth in the world and domestic economies and the improved competitiveness of our manufacturers, there is every reason to believe that this growth should continue.
—Would you put your money into manufacturing or into real estate? That is the question.
—I do not know.
—That is the decision they have to make.
—It is purely hypothetical as far as I am concerned.
—You don't have to--

—Well, Senator Lewis has his usual clever interjections but he ought to have a look at the figures for the growth of manufacturing investment. He can interject in here and carry on, as he always does, but the figures for growth and manufacturing investment are very encouraging, more encouraging than they ever were during the 27 years of Liberal Government in this country, more impressive. The growth in other manufacturing statistics is, of course, even more impressive still. The National Institute of Economic and Industry Research, which has not always been bullish about the future of Australian industry, suggested at the conference that there could be a major boom in manufacturing investment over the next few years. It identified a number of areas with particularly bright prospects.

ANSWER.PARA: One danger is to become complacent about what has been achieved and forget that much still remains to be done. In particular, more Australian companies need to think about the benefits of entering export markets. If one looks at the sectoral statements, industry by industry, one can see that corporate leaders made this point themselves at the Manufacturing Outlook Conference. Some companies already exporting still view overseas markets as somewhere to sell products that are surplus to local demand rather than a continuing part of their market.

On the question of investment, honourable senators might be interested in what a member of the German BDI investment mission-that is the German Confederation of Industry-visiting Australia had to say last week about investment opportunities in Australia. It ties in with what some of the speakers at the BIE conference were saying, and it might be beneficial to Senator Lewis. This senior German business leader, in referring to the need for German manufacturers to relocate some of their facilities abroad, had this to say:

Australia is very attractive. The impression is that in government, business and to some extent in trade unions, you are moving in the right direction. This is a healthy foundation for doing business . . . remarkable changes have taken place--
since he was last here in 1983. He continued:
It is encouraging when people advance that dramatically in a few years. You immediately wonder what business you could do together.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the media release of 31 October 1988 by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in which he announced that the Commonwealth Auditor-General will undertake an audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission and that an officer of the Department of Finance will work with the Commission on finance matters. In view of the serious allegations which have been made about mismanagement within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, why has the Minister excluded the Department from the audit? What other investigations have been initiated into the management of that Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no deliberate attempt to exclude the Department of Aboriginal Affairs from any proper surveillance by the Auditor-General. To suggest that is to misconceive the situation completely. The fact is that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is subject to continuous and proper audit of its activities, and I believe that came out during the deliberations of Estimates Committee E when many of the allegations concerning the operations of the Department-and which were, for example, partly based on a letter I think from the Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association-were refuted by the departmental officers present under intense questioning by Senator Tambling and Senator Short.

ANSWER.PARA: Those officers were able to refute those allegations and assertions with confidence, because their refutations and rejections were properly based on procedures which were devised, and which are always available for review, by the Auditor-General's Office and Department of Finance personnel. In other words, it was indicated quite clearly in Estimates Committee E that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has sufficient procedures and mechanisms in place to assess properly the propriety and managerial expertise that went into the decisions relating to the various programs for which it was responsible. It was in relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission that the most intense questioning and allegations were directed by both Senator Tambling and Senator Short, and it is in relation to their allegations that the Minister thought it proper to invite the Auditor-General and the Minister for Finance to give some special assistance. I would have thought that that should be a cause for considerable satisfaction, not the suggestion of a very artificial dichotomy or contrast between the Department and the Commission as far as the Department's proper supervision by the Auditor-General is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister acknowledges that the Department is subject to routine proper procedures and mechanism checks by the Auditor-General. Is he implying that the Aboriginal Development Commission has not in the past been subject to proper procedures and mechanism checks by the Auditor-General? Also, I reiterate my original question: What other investigations have been initiated into the management problems of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs?

—Senator Tambling is the one asserting management problems in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. During hearings of Estimates Committee E his allegations and assertions concerning those management problems were dealt with by officers in a very calm and fair response to his constant questioning. The fact is that he did not come back at them. He barely laid a glove on them as far as the departmental supervision of various programs was concerned. Senator Tambling did raise some matters in relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission and whilst, as I have said, they largely remain allegations they require some special procedures. I believe the Minister has shown his resolve, as has the Government, to ensure that moneys that are devoted by the Australian people to these programs are properly disbursed. That will be achieved.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the seriousness of the present locust plague occurring in Africa and, in particular, in the Horn of Africa? Is he also aware that the Ethiopian Government has refused to cooperate with the Desert Locust Control Organisation (DLCO), of which it is a member with Kenya, Sudan and Somalia, in that it has said it will not allow aeroplanes from the organisation to fly over Ethiopian territory to undertake aerial spraying and, if they do so, such planes could be shot down? If the locust plague is not controlled because of the Ethiopian attitude and accordingly food production in Ethiopia is reduced, then Australia may well be asked by Ethiopia to increase its food aid to that country. If this is true, and in view of the fact that the Australian Government has been a major food donor to Ethiopia, will the Government make the strongest possible representations to the Ethiopian Government to reverse its decision and cooperate with the DLCO in its efforts to control and end the severe locust plague?

—I am aware, but only from press reports, of the matter to which Senator Schacht refers. I am not in a position to provide a comprehensive answer to his question at this time although he gave me notice of it shortly before Question Time. I will arrange for an answer to be obtained as soon as possible and I will give it to Senator Schacht as soon as I can.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask you, Mr President, whether you have become aware of the multitudes of bogong moths which are festooning the marble canyons of Parliament House. Are you pleased that these free-ranging creatures have chosen Australia's Parliament House for their breeding place, perhaps establishing a yearly event like the annual return of swallows to Capistrano? If you are not pleased with the moths--

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a serious question, so please bear with me-I am on the Animal Welfare Committee! If you, Mr President, are not pleased with the moths, do you contemplate spraying? QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice whether he has seen an article in the Adelaide Advertiser dated 31 October 1988 in which Senator Hill is quoted as alleging that South Australia:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . may get a downgraded and ineffective National Crime Authority office in Adelaide . . .
Will the Minister comment on this allegation?

TALK.START.PARA: —It so happens that I do have in front of me the Advertiser dated 31 October 1988 in which Senator Hill put out a dire warning that `South Australia may get a downgraded and ineffective National Crime Authority office in Adelaide'. He based that on certain inferences which he drew from the course of business in Estimates Committee E. Apparently he thought that this Government and the South Australian Government were prepared to face the serious allegations concerning corruption in the police force of South Australia in relation to organised criminal activity generally in a way which would be ineffectual and indeed quite disproportionate to the problem that has been said to exist there. Indeed, I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate and, in particular, Senator Hill, that Senator Hill's fears and his raising of misgivings in the community are totally unfounded. The Attorney-General, Chris Sumner, has announced today that he has obtained the support of the Commonwealth Government, which, of course, was always available to him, to grant an additional reference to the National Crime Authority to investigate allegations of criminal activity and corruption in South Australia. This clears the way, I believe, for the establishment of an office of the National Crime Authority in South Australia to investigate these matters.
—You are supporting the office now?

—I have always supported the establishment of a National Crime Authority office. I believe that it is an astute observation by the South Australian Government that the National Crime Authority, because of the coercive powers it has when a reference is granted to it and the expertise it has accumulated over several years, is the best body in Australia to undertake this task. Whilst the South Australian Government, either unilaterally or without the assistance of the Commonwealth Government, cannot establish and give a reference to the NCA in Adelaide, I am confident that the intergovernmental committee, when it meets to discuss the request by South Australia, given the support of the Commonwealth and of Mr Justice Stewart of the National Crime Authority, will decide that an NCA office should be established in South Australia. The South Australian Government has put its money where its mouth is, if you like, by approving funds for the establishment and running costs of such an NCA office. Those running costs are thought to be in the region of $1.1m per year, which is a substantial sum of money, subject to operational requirements.
—Why wouldn't you say that in the Estimates the other night?

—Senator Hill asks why we did not announce it to him, why we did not make the announcement when he asked certain questions in the Estimates Committee hearing. I do not regard Estimates Committee E as the world; Senator Hill might, but I do not. I regard this parliamentary chamber as the proper forum to make these announcements. That is what I am doing. It is probably what Mr Sumner in South Australia is doing at this very moment.
—Who is going to head it up?
—Senator Hill keeps making interjections about who is going to head it up. I do not know who is going to head it up at this stage.
—You are going to employ a counsel to do it, aren't you?

—No, we are not. Senator Hill makes the assertion that we are going to appoint some senior counsel to run the office in Adelaide. We are not. We are going to seek this chamber's support for an amendment to the National Crime Authority legislation to allow an additional member to be appointed with all the powers and status of a member of the National Crime Authority in order fully to supervise and carry out this reference with all the supervision and powers that are required.
—That is very good.

—After several weeks of making allegations that this Government and the South Australian Government were not interested in pursuing this matter effectively, I am pleased to hear Senator Hill now saying that the decision taken is a very good decision. I concur with his assessment. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Orders of the Senate contain a prohibition on Senate committees and joint committees of which senators are members meeting during sittings of the Senate. The relevant provision is now contained in new standing order 300a, which was adopted by way of a sessional order on 22 September 1987, and which relaxed the prohibition to the extent of allowing Senate and joint committees to hold only deliberative meetings in private session during sittings of the Senate. Prior to 1983, the Public Accounts Committee adhered to this rule, and, when it wished to meet during sittings of the Senate, sought the permission of the Senate to do so, as do other committees. In 1983, the Public Accounts Committee began to meet during sittings of the Senate without the permission of the Senate. It did so on the basis of a legal opinion to the effect that subsection 6 (A) (1) of the Public Accounts Committee Act, which provides for the Committee or its Chairman to determine its times and places of meeting, empowers the Committee to override the rule contained in the Senate Standing Orders. This situation was considered by the Senate Standing Orders Committee which, in a report presented on 6 October 1983, refuted the view taken by the Public Accounts Committee and recommended that, until the matter was clarified by an amendment of the Public Accounts Committee Act, the Committee should comply with the Standing Orders.

INTERJECT.PARA: In 1987, the Public Accounts Committee presented a report disputing the views of the Standing Orders Committee and reasserting its belief that it had the power to meet during the sittings of the Senate. The Standing Orders Committee, on 13 May 1987, presented a further report demonstrating that the view taken by the Public Accounts Committee was based on a number of misconceptions. The Standing Orders Committee suggested that the Senate consider whether any relaxation of the prohibition on committee meetings during sittings of the Senate should be made. The Senate considered the matter and adopted new standing order 300a, which has already been referred to.

Recently it came to my attention that the Public Accounts Committee was continuing to disregard the decision of the Senate and was holding public hearings during Senate sittings. The Senate having so recently made a deliberate decision as to joint committee meetings during its sittings, I considered that I had a duty to report the actions of the Public Accounts Committee to the Senate. Before doing so I wrote to the Chairman of the Committee. I table a copy of my letter and the Chairman's response. It is clear from the Chairman's letter that the Committee intends to continue to disregard the decision of the Senate. If the Public Accounts Committee persists in this attitude, it would be open to the Senate to direct that senators not attend meetings of the Committee during sittings of the Senate. I now place the matter before the Senate for its consideration. I also present to the Senate the relevant extracts from the reports to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 August, Senator Chaney asked me a number of questions relating to the national wage decision and I undertook to respond after consultation with the Minister for Industrial Relations. My response is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission stated in its August national wage case decision that the structural efficiency principle would be the key element in the new system of wage fixation. This principle was designed to provide incentive and scope for parties to examine their awards. The Commission made it plain that the principle was not to be applied in a negative, cost-cutting manner. Its purpose was to facilitate the type of fundamental review necessary to ensure that existing award structures were relevant to the modern competitive needs of industry and in the best interests of management and workers. It is here that the foundation for real productivity improvements will be laid.

Parties gaining access to wage increases under the new wage principles are required to commit themselves formally to co-operate positively in a fundamental review of their award with a view to implementing measures to improve the efficiency of industry and provide workers with access to more varied, fulfilling and better paid jobs. Such reviews are to be monitored and assisted as necessary by the Commission. Moreover, in February 1989 the Commission will be convening hearings to consider detailed reports on progress on individual award reviews in order to monitor the effectiveness of the system and consider any matters of general principle requiring resolution.

The fundamental review of awards envisaged under the new wage system is expected to result in substantial productivity improvements over time. Given the magnitude of the changes involved, implementation of restructuring and other changes will take considerable time and the benefits for efficiency and productivity will be generated over the medium to longer term.

That is the substance of the answer which Senator Chaney sought, by way of question, on 30 August. On 28 October, Senator Chaney wrote me a letter on the matter seeking further information. There is a further part of the answer which I seek to have incorporated in Hansard

Wage increases in the initial stages of the new system have been flowing somewhat faster than originally anticipated. However, in the absence of wage data for even the first quarter of 1988/89 it is too early to suggest that Budget forecasts need revision. Moreover, the flow of wage increases is indicative of substantial improvements in industrial relationships between employers and unions. The parties are building on the positive experience of second tier bargaining by agreeing to wage increases that create a favourable climate for the major review of industrial awards now in train as part of the new system.

With regard to its own employees, the Government has taken note of the Commission's direction that the operative dates for wage increases should be negotiated between the parties and have regard to the circumstances in the particular awards or sectors concerns. In that context, and having regard to the Government's wages policy and to the budgetary implications of early payment of the wage increases, the Government argued that most salary increases for its employees should not apply before mid-October 1988. This view has been accepted by the Commission which has emphasised the need for a staggered approach to the granting of wage rises. A similar approach has been adopted where the Commonwealth accepts responsibility for funding. However this date has been departed from where special circumstances existed.

Presumably all parliamentarians share the common goal of reducing not only the number of people who are reliant on unemployment benefit but also the duration of time on unemployment benefit, not purely because of cost but, more particularly, because of the period during which people have to suffer the indignity of not being able to get a job when they want one.

The whole question of young Australians, the unemployment benefit, and what we should be doing about the problem of high numbers of young Australians needing unemployment benefit reminds me of a scheme launched in August-September 1985 called the Priority One scheme. I am sure Government senators remember it well. At that time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised to provide 70,000 traineeship in our bicentennial year: that happens to be this year, 1988. Yet if one looks at statistics to see how many young Australians are benefiting from the Priority One scheme by the provision of traineeships, one will see that 15,000 traineeships is the target for this year. I do not need to labour the point. Thankfully, after some time the Government realised the error of its ways and has admitted the Priority One scheme was a failure; that expectations of young Australians were raised most unfairly; and that it was not able to deliver.

I was in one sense pleased to take part in the debate to criticise the Priority One scheme. I said that it was purely Government public relations, it was media hype, it was simply selling the Government, and that not enough thought had gone into it. Because not enough had gone into it, the traineeships would not eventuate and there would still be young Australians on unemployment benefit. As I say, thankfully the Government admits that failure, but it has done something else, as I mentioned earlier. It has announced a committee to coordinate Government policy for young Australians. I do not complain about that. I hope that policy for young Australians is properly coordinated. However, this is the sixth year of office of this Government. Six years on, the Government is trying to tell young Australians that it is making a genuine attempt to coordinate policy on their behalf. Proper working groups are to be set up to consult with young Australians and with those volunteer groups who play a part in helping young Australians in order to obtain their views.

It all sounds very similar. The name tag `Priority One' has gone and, thankfully, the publicity to advertise the Government, rather than doing something sensible for young Australians, has also gone. Nonetheless, we still have the noises of consultation. You will remember, Mr Deputy President, the Priority One phone-in-commonly referred to by young Australians as `squawk to Hawke'. We have had consultations and a number of surveys. Young Australians have been consulted ad infinitum. I think we are entitled, in the sixth year of this Government, to ask what it will do to coordinate policy. We do not just want to hear that a committee will be set up. The Government has had six years to look at this area.

If the Government takes some notice of this very short term advice, perhaps we will find in the Department of Social Security annual report next year something more about the unemployment benefit than a simple outline of what category one has to come under to obtain the benefit. Hopefully, we will see something about what the Government has done to ensure that fewer and fewer young Australians require the unemployment benefit and that those who do require the unemployment benefit do so for a lesser period than is the case now.

I want to draw the Senate's attention to a couple of aspects of the annual report of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation. First, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) is involved in one or two rather important efforts to improve the efficiency of converting livestock to meat. I hope that the Government does not see fit to cut back funding to the CSIRO in this area, as it has for all sorts of reasons in other areas around Australia. The CSIRO, in studying beef conversion cost reduction, as it is called, has for several years been looking at a new method of slaughtering and dressing cattle at its research laboratories. It is finding that by using mechanical methods of cutting up meat, slaughtering is becoming more efficient. As we all realise, one of the dearest components of any manual industry is the labour itself. Bringing automation into the slaughtering operation will reduce not only the heavy strains on the slaughtermen themselves but also the cost factor.

The report also notes that there has been quite a deal of work done on improving meat inspection. Meat inspection has been brought to the notice of everyone in this Senate over the last 12 months, particularly as a result of organochlorins in meat. There certainly needs to be more study into and work on a more efficient meat inspection system. In particular, the annual report notes that the Corporation is looking at a concept called total quality assurance which, if it comes to pass, will revolutionise the whole meat inspection procedure. The interesting point is that it is a similar concept to that used by the Japanese for car inspections. One might ask what the two industries have in common, but I suppose at the end of the day the most important thing is that we improve quality. As well, this total quality assurance system will reduce inspection costs by between 30 and 50 per cent. The Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation is looking at that at the moment. I wish it the best of success with that project.

I also want to bring to the notice of the Senate another innovative idea involving enhancing the value of skins, hides and by-products. If successful, this project could revolutionise the Australian tanning industry, and it is hoped that this practice will begin next year. It involves a prototype laser machine being developed for the fellmongering process, and if that laser technology is successful it will remove the pollution problems encountered in fellmongering. It will reduce the time required for the tanning process from hours to minutes. If it is successful, it will open up a new industry to Australia-the downstreaming of hides. That certainly needs to have more work done on it. I hope that that system does come to fruition. This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to five Bounty Acts and one Subsidy Act.
The Bill's major purpose is to make amendments to the Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Act 1981, and the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981, and the Bounty (Bed Sheeting) Act 1977;

II) To extend the life of the first two Bounty schemes until 30 June 1995, as part of the Government's post 1988 textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan; and to implement the phasing-down of assistance under the schemes to a final rate of 30%, as announced in that plan and the 25 May 1988 economic statement, (Clause 4, Schedule 1); and

II) To increase the maximum annual amount of Bounty available for payment under the third scheme as announced in the (TCF) plan, from $600,000 to $3.2 million, commencing on 1 March 1989 and operating until 28 February 1993 when the scheme will be reviewed (Clause 4, Schedule 1).

Under the Government's post 1988 TCF plan, the Bounty rate for the Printed Fabric Bounty, (which is paid for the printing of certain apparel fabrics) was originally scheduled to be phased down from 56% to 30% by the end of the plan i.e. 1 March 1996. However, as part of the changes announced by the Government in the May economic statement, it was decided to shorten the TCF plan by eight months, i.e. the plan is now to operate until 30 June 1995. Accordingly, the phasing period originally proposed in the TCF plan has been recalculated so that the 30% end point is reached by that date. This Bill proposes amendments to the Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Act 1981 in schedule 1 to the Bill, to give legislative effect to this segment of the TCF plan.

With regard to the Textile Yarns Bounty, the TCF plan proposed that all products eligible to receive bounty under the Bounty Scheme would be paid at a uniform rate of 30% by 1 March 1994. The only amendment to the timetable for the phased amendments to existing rates of bounty announced in the TCF plan relates to the pace of reduction in bounty assistance for continuous filament polyamide and polyester yarns. Under the TCF plan the rate of bounty was to be reduced from the current 47.5% of factory cost value added to 45% on 1 March 1989, with a reduction to 37.5% on 1 March 1993, and a final drop to 30% on 1 March 1994. In the May Economic Statement the Government decided to slightly accelerate the reduction, and it is now proposed to reduce the amount of bounty payable to 42.5% on 1 March 1989, then to 35% on 1 March 1993 before finally reaching 30% on 1 March 1994. Further, similar to the Printed Fabrics Bounty, this scheme is to operate until 30 June 1995. The proposed amendments to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 in Schedule 1 to the Bill give legislative effect to this segment of the TCF plan.

The final amendment to existing legislation that is necessary to implement the Government's TCF plan is the proposed amendment to the Bounty (Bed Sheeting) Act 1977. This Bill proposes to increase the maximum amount of bounty that may be appropriated to that scheme by Parliament in any one twelve month period from $600,000 per annum to $3,200,000 per annum, until the scheme ends on 28 February 1993. This increased annual ceiling will assist the revitalisation of this important industry in the TCF sector.

In addition to the above, a number of technical drafting amendments to clarify or effect consequential changes to two bounty schemes and one subsidy scheme are proposed. These are set out in detail in the Bill's explanatory memorandum.
Financial Impact Statement

The proposed extension of the Textile Yarn and Printed Fabric Bounties is expected to result in total bounty outlays for both of these schemes of about $300 million over the 3 financial years 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91. This figure incorporates the estimated savings arising from the changes announced by the Government in the post-1988 TCF plan and the May 25 Economic Statement of $0.8 million in 1988-89, $4.0 million in 1989-90 and $5.5 million in 1990-91.

The proposed amendments to the Bed Sheeting Bounty will require the Commonwealth to outlay a maximum of $12.8 million between 1 March 1989 and 28 February 1993. The 4 month bounty period 1 November 1988 to 28 February 1989 is subject to a ceiling of $200,000 (a pro-rating of the current $600,000 ceiling for 4 months).
The amendments to the other bounty schemes and the amendment to the subsidy scheme have no direct financial implications.

Any community that does not address that relationship and that ratio is utterly irresponsible. It is ridiculous and irresponsible of the Opposition to suggest that we do not have, first of all, the obligation and, secondly, the right to put in place committees and mechanisms which will address precisely that process. Of the 41 samples sent to the United States 38 showed residues of at least one pesticide or solvent. On average three pesticides and five solvents were detected in the samples. DDE, which is a breakdown product of DDT, was detected in every one of the blood samples analysed. There was a moderate but significant correlation between the chemicals tested. That is people high in one chemical were likely to show high levels of residual toxicity from other chemicals as well.

These four practitioners, who do not claim expertise in toxicology, sent their samples to the United States, the experts in the world. They have subsequently sent another 56 samples, the results of which are likely to be known in the next 48 hours. They are alerting us to the fact that we could be moving into an extremely challenging era as far as these toxic residues are concerned. They admit that they are clinicians and not toxicologists. However, they have passed these samples to an authority that is representative of the Center for Disease Control of Atlanta and the Environmental Protection Agency in the United States. It has on it representatives of government toxicology authorities, prominent immunologists, prominent immunopathologists, prominent toxicological pathologists and representatives of government medical agencies that are charged with the investigation of such matters in the United States.
