TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on behalf of the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who is absent today. The subject of agricultural and veterinary chemicals is a large and very controversial one. There can be no doubt that the availability and use of agrochemicals has contributed significantly to agricultural production and to the prosperity of this country. The control and certain insect-borne diseases such as malaria, yellow fever and sleeping sickness has become possible only with the introduction of modern insecticides. It is essential to remember that the very safest pesticides must be used carefully and in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions if adverse effects are to be avoided. Even then it is necessary to monitor their use closely to ensure that unintended and unforeseen effects do not occur.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate on this issue over recent weeks has focused on two issues: firstly the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill and, secondly, the proposal that there be a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia.

Let me reiterate the objectives of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill. They are, firstly, to protect and enhance trade and commerce in agricultural produce and livestock; secondly, to assist in the conduct of agricultural and veterinary oper- ations in all or any of the Territories; thirdly, to minimise any undue hazard, to the public, the environment, users and agricultural produce and livestock, from the application of chemical products in accordance with recommendations for their use; fourthly, to minimise the need for separate evaluation of chemical products by the registering authorities of States and Territories; fifthy, to ensure that agricultural and veterinary chemicals are effective in the uses for which they are cleared; and, sixthly, to ensure that evaluations of chemical products are carried out in a timely and efficient manner.

The legislation will provide the basis of the Commonwealth-State clearance process which ensures that efficacy, public and occupational health and environmental impact are fully evaluated prior to approval, that claims made by manufactures can be substantiated and that there are no unintended side effects from the use of agricultural and veterinary chemical products. Research by governments, industry and private sector research bodies into chemicals already in use is ongoing and the clearance authority will have improved access to the results of that very important work.

The clearance process ensures that agricultural and veterinary chemicals approved for use within Australia will perform as claimed and will not jeopardise the quality, or indeed the very production of crops and livestock. Only safe and quality products are approved for marketing and then only under strict conditions of use. This legislative approach has been endorsed by the Australian Agricultural Council and all States have participated in its development and will continue to do so in its administration. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen noted, the Bill requires that the Commonwealth and States enter into an agreement to ensure that Commonwealth and State roles are well defined and complementary. I hope that the doubts of Senator Lewis about Queensland's participation are not based on fact. I feel sure that Senator Bjelke-Petersen would ensure that Queensland was cooperating in this vital matter. Continued Commonwealth-State cooperation can be assured and will be vital to the successful administration of the legislation.

The goal in controlling agricultural and veterinary chemicals is to ensure that primary producers and, indeed, all segments of society are offered maximum protection from possible adverse effects but, at the same time, are not denied the benefits that such chemicals can offer. The clearance and registration process enables government to exercise control over availability, levels of use, claims, labelling and packaging and also provides reassurance to the public that agrochemicals are safe providing they are used correctly and responsibly. It will be the responsibility of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council established under the legislation to ensure that these control measures are in place.

I am encouraged by Opposition comments that it supports the Bill and the objectives it seeks to pursue which the Government believes will improve the assessment and control procedures to the benefit of primary producers and the wider community. The international community will also see that the Commonwealth is playing a positive and purposeful role in agrochemicals regulation.

The second aspect of the debate has been the merit-or otherwise-of a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. It has been argued that the introduction of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill coupled with the current Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) study into chemical residues in agricultural products makes such an inquiry unnecessary. That clearance and registration play a central role in the control of pesticides is not in doubt. Pesticide registration and control of pesticides, however, are not synonymous and although clearance and registration are essential components of the control process their limitations should also be emphasised. Therefore, legislative control is only one component of the proposed select committee's terms of reference.

Throughout the Opposition's argument no one has thought it necessary to clearly define the purpose and scope of the ASTEC study. It is a study into chemical residues in agricultural products. In undertaking its review ASTEC is to consider: the national and international mechanisms to ensure that appropriate standards are developed; the national and international implementation of those standards; whether residues are a cause for consumer concern; the opportunities for the development of new analytical techniques and/or new and safer agricultural and veterinary chemicals through strategic research; other opportunities for contributions through strategic research such as the development of decontamination methods; and the potential for the contamination of agricultural products through the non-agricultural use of chemicals.

Its objective is therefore the consideration of residues and their implications for consumers and international trade and it will provide a sound base for the select committee to work from. As I have already said the use of chemicals in agriculture is a large and controversial subject which extends beyond the clearance and registration process and residues in food. It is these other areas such as environmental protection, social and economic impact, alternative pest control strategies, integrated pest management techniques and non-chemical pest control measures, all of which have strengths and limitations, that the inquiry will also focus upon. The Government supports the inquiry because it does go further than registration and residues.

The Government rejected the Opposition sponsored witch-hunt into the beef residue crisis a few months ago. The Government saw no point in dredging up 20-year-old issues such as dibromochloropropane of the Industrial Bio-test Laboratories (IBT) affair which resulted in improved standards of good laboratory practice. In respect of Australia, they have been largely laid to rest with the removal of products implicated with IBT Laboratories or the provision of replacement toxicology studies.

I would also hope, and I anticipate that it will be the case, that the inquiry is forward looking and constructive and will seek to address important issues such as the social costs of pesticide use; the practicality of alternative pest control strategies; the adequacy of research into biological and integrated pest management techniques applicable to Australia; the possible effects of chemicals on air, water and soil; as well as the benefits that are derived from chemical use and which are seldom documented or acknowledged.

An inquiry concentrating on old but evergreen chemical issues will be unproductive, but one along constructive lines will be a challenge and will demonstrate to the community and other countries that we have the maturity and technical competence to openly discuss controversial agrochemical issues which are of concern, not only to Australia, but to all countries where agricultural and veterinary chemicals are important elements in agricultural production. Improvements and innovation are not encouraged by burying one's head in the sand and pretending that some very real issues do not exist.

In conclusion I wish to correct some misunderstandings about the national residue survey (NRS) which appear to have pervaded the ranks of the Opposition. It has been suggested on several occasions that the national residue survey failed Australian primary producers by not detecting organochlorine residues in beef prior to detections in the United States of America in 1987. This is incorrect and fails to recognise that the NRS is a quality assurance program and not a quality control device. Without analysing every animal or piece of fruit it is not possible to prevent occasional residue violations and product rejection. The NRS has been reviewed by authorities in the United States of America on several occasions and found to be satisfactory. Annual results have routinely been provided to the United States Department of Agriculture. Quarterly reports have also been routinely provided to State authorities and commodity organisations within Australia. The results of organochlorine monitoring via the NRS have been confirmed through some 600,000 analyses since mid-1987. The national residue survey had demonstrated organochlorine violations to be only 0.4 per cent, which is comparable with, if not better than the records of other countries. DDT violations were only 0.02 per cent and none had been detected since 1977. Despite goods results across all product categories covered, the NRS is being upgraded to ensure that the survey remains equivalent to or better than those of our trading partners.

I commend the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill to honourable senators and indicate the Government's support of the proposed Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia as a further commitment on the part of the Government to practical and sound agrochemicals management in this country.

``(a) significantly contradicts any information furnished to the Council under this Act; or

(b) indicates that the use of the chemical product in accordance with the claims or recommendations for its use may have an unintended harmful effect or may be significantly less effective than was set out in the application;''.

Clause 22 gives considerable concern to the industry. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia Ltd (AVCA) has written to Mr Bruce Lloyd, who is the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, in a letter dated 10 May 1988, about the details of this Bill. I will quote from the letter in relation to this matter. It says:

The principal concern to AVCA is Clause 22 (1). AVCA believes it is unnecessarily severe, potentially open to a wide range of interpretations and would be impractical to implement in its current form in the Bill.

Clause 22 (1) (a) requires a person or a company to provide, in writing, information which contradicts any information furnished to the Council or risk a harsh financial penalty or potential imprisonment for up to five years or both. AVCA suggests this is a harsh, unnecessary and totally out of context inclusion.

This is reinforced under Clause 22 (1) (b) where the potential is for any person or group of persons to suggest (and only a suggestion is necessary-as provided in Clause 17 (1)) that the cleared product has a `unintended harmful effect' or say that it was only 90% effective rather than the 95% effective as shown by field trials for these extreme penalties to be applied.
The debate over either what is an `unintended harmful effect' or a `less effective product' is open to considerable variation of interpretation.

AVCA strongly objects to this Clause in its current format, particularly where we note in Clause 45 that no proceedings can be taken against the Commonwealth or a person involved with the Council relating to the use of a chemical product.
The letter goes on to say:

AVCA suggests that implementation of this Section would be impractical and seeks either deletion or considerable modification of this Clause, consistent with existing requirements relating to product efficacy.

It is for the reasons set out in that letter that the Opposition has moved the circulated amendment. This amendment is designed to protect the person to whom a clearance has been granted from a situation that could arise if there were any insignificant changes in the information available about a particular chemical-for example, if the efficacy of a product was shown as a result of experimentation or new data to change by even one per cent, the company concerned could be prosecuted and exposed to serious penalty. The insertion of the words `significant' and `significantly', in our view, remedy this defect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in Senator Lewis's opening remarks when he said that this clause greatly disturbs the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia Ltd, because, if I remember correctly, Senator Brownhill pointed out in the second reading debate that AVCA had recently expanded its membership to include formulators and marketers in Australia. SPEECH.PARA: Clearance and Registration Committee (chaired by Mr Hermann Mani, Ciba-Geigy); AVCA Public Affairs Committee (chaired by Mr Hugh Lander, Schering); Insecticide Resistance Action Committee (chaired by Mr Keith Alcock, ICI); Herbicide Resistance Action Committee (chaired by Mr Peter Howat, Hoechst); Fungicide Resistance Action Committee (chaired by Mr Jim Swain, Ciba-Geigy); Health and Safety Committee (chaired by Dr Noel Humphry, ICI) . . .

If that information is withheld, then very severe penalties should be exacted against those large companies.

There are numbers of examples of major chemical companies and major groupings of chemical companies around the world which, in the past, have withheld vital information from the relevant authorities, and the withholding of that information has exposed large numbers of workers and people in the community to extremely toxic hazards. I gave several examples in my speech on the second reading, in relation to DVCP and the registration of a drug. Another example would be the way in which the Manufacturing Chemists Association of the United States, between 1972 and 1974, withheld information on the extreme carcinogenicity of vinyl chloride monomer. Thousands of workers were exposed to very high levels of one of the most potent cancer causing agents. That information was withheld from the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency in the United States. There are numerous examples of this sort of thing having happened in the past and it is vital that not only these sorts of provisions be written in but also that the penalties be very substantial.

(2) Page 18, subclause 22 (3), lines 28 to 31, leave out the subclause.

The amendments relate to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I find it quite fascinating that the Australian Labor Party mans that Committee and produces these reports, but apparently it is unable to effect any changes through Caucus which, I remind the Committee, we used to do when we were in government. If we were not able to get it through the party room we would come into the chamber and move the amendments. I do not know where the members of the Committee are. The Committee, which is chaired by Senator Cooney, keeps producing excellent reports but they are no good unless they are implemented. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its ninth report of 1988, issued on 1 June 1988, deals with the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill. The report deals with clause 22 which refers to the reversal of the onus of proof. We are talking about a criminal matter. We are talking about penalties of $250,000 or five years imprisonment. They are really quite horrific penalties. In addition, the clause reverses the onus of proof. The Senate Committee said:

If enacted, clause 22 would provide that certain persons (holders of certificates of clearance issued by the Council) are required to notify the Council of any new information at variance with information previously provided to the Council, or which may indicate that the use of chemicals in accordance with published recommendations may be harmful, or less effective, than originally represented to the Council. Failure to notify the Council may lead to prosecution.

Clause 22 (3) would reverse the onus of proof in a prosecution under the provision. It is a defence to a charge, under the clause, that the person charged did not possess, and had no means of access to, the information referred to in the clause. Although the matters which would constitute the defence are such as would be peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant, it is difficult to see how a rebuttal of these matters would cause undue expense or difficulty to the prosecution.
The clause is accordingly drawn to the Senate's attention in that, by reversing the onus of proof in a criminal prosecution it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

This is a matter that the Senate has taken to its heart continually, firstly in the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which tells the Government day after day that it will not allow it to reverse the onus of proof in regulations. This sort of provision is exactly the reason why the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was introduced, to draw attention to things such as the reversal of the onus of proof, and to say to governments of all ilk-whether a Labor Party government or a coalition government-`You must not reverse the onus of proof'. The proof of guilt must always rest on the Crown. Certainly, the accused in any case may be given certain defences that it is entitled to raise in circumstances in which it may not raise them otherwise, but in the long run the onus of proof must rest on the Crown. That is what the argument is all about.

The amendments which I moved were drawn up by an expert Senate officer to change the legislation so the Crown would still have the onus of proving. In other words by leaving out the words `being information of which the holder might reasonably be expected to have knowledge or to which the holder might reasonably be expected to have access', inserting the words `being information which the holder knows or has access to' and leaving out the third subclause the holder of the information would have the defence available but the final onus of proof would rest on the Crown. I urge the Senate to adopt the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the Senate is the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill which provides on an annual basis the provision to the States of Commonwealth income tax sharing revenue for their own governmental purposes. The Bill authorises expenditure by the Commonwealth of $12.4 billion to the various States for those purposes. Altogether this represents about 15 per cent of the total of Commonwealth Government expenditures. It is interesting to note that, in the recent Budget announcement of the cuts in government expenditure of some $700m, 70 per cent has come about by virtue of cuts made to the financial grants to the States. Although it is no doubt proper to put pressure on the States to be more accountable for their expenditure-and to do so in such a way as to ensure that taxpayers get benefit for their dollars which are so hard earned and which we paid to the Hawke-Keating Government-the fact is that this represents a degree of hypocrisy when one considers that the Commonwealth Government cuts represent only 30 per cent of the total reductions in expenditures by the Commonwealth. In other words, a very small percentage of the cuts is attributable to this Government's own restrictions on its own operations. It gives the lie to the claims by the Hawke-Keating Government that it is exercising restraint over its own activities. In fact, most of the restraint is being exercised over State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to questions about the basics of the Budget. Obviously that Budget, which was put down in this place only two months ago, is already falling apart. We have seen in the outcomes for the first three months of the financial year a rather worse balance of payments situation than was estimated in the Budget. We now see a figure of around $4 billion of deficit compared with a total estimate for the full 12 months of $9.5 billion. The figure is almost up to the half way mark and only a quarter of the year has gone by.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about inflation?

—And as my colleague says, inflation is going through the roof, as every member of the community knows. The measurement estimated by the Government of 4.5 per cent for the financial year obviously is not achievable by this Government. Clearly we have the situation for the first quarter where almost half of that amount has come about in three months, compared with the 4.5 per cent estimated by the Government for the full 12 months. Obviously the figures are very rubbery indeed, and it would be a brave Mr Keating who would continue to claim that he is the world's greatest Treasurer. He may well claim that he is the world's greatest creative accountant, but he certainly would not rate as a financial manager.
—It's going the way of the Whitlam Government.

—Indeed, as Senator Watson points out, the whiff of the Whitlam Government is about here. We can smell the rising inflation that we saw in 1974 and the balance of payments crisis of 1974 which led to huge unemployment and lengthening of job queues under the disastrous Whitlam Government which laid the basis of so much difficulty for the present time.
—You haven't got a Fraser.

—The Minister talks about Mr Fraser. I would remind him that since 1983 this Government all by itself has quadrupled this country's debt. We now owe $100 billion to the rest of the world. When Mr Fraser went out of office in 1983, the figure was only $30 billion or thereabouts. Now $100 billion has to be repaid. Even Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, has said in this very place that, unless something is done, we are headed down the Argentinean road.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to go on at too great length about this because, although there is so much to tell, there are many other stories that I would like to bring out tonight. We must realise first and foremost that the Government is hitting the average family man right, left and centre. This is causing enormous difficulty and, as we have shown in figures put down in the Senate and in the House of Representatives, the average family man, with his spouse at home and not working, with two children, taking into account all social security benefits, compared with the time when Mr Fraser went out of office is in real terms $56 a week worse off today than he was in 1983. Clearly this is a disaster for the average family. The results of the by-elections in Adelaide, Port Adelaide and Oxley clearly demonstrate that the people of Australia have had enough of this Government and are giving very solid messages as to how they want to see this country governed. We know that interest rates are rising and are continuing to rise, and that will have a great impact on the standards of living of the average family.

This Bill contains an interesting innovation. Last May in the mini-Budget the Government decided to allow local government bodies and State governments to charge Commonwealth authorities the various taxes-payroll taxes, rates on their property and so on-whereas previously that had been prohibited by the Constitution. That would be fine if it were all on the basis of user pays, making Commonwealth bodies properly accountable for their expenditures and running their businesses in the most efficient manner. But what the Government is also doing-and this is causing a great deal of concern, particularly among local government people-is saying, `You can charge Commonwealth bodies those taxes, but we will take back 90 per cent of it by reducing the amount of grants we will give'. Therefore, there is a net gain to the people who are running local government and State governments of only 10 per cent of the total amount they will have to charge. This will put local government to a great deal of trouble in having to value properties and to work out how much they will charge. There will be enormous equity problems in distributing funds among the various local governments, not all of whom have Commonwealth authorities such as Telecom Australia or Australia Post sited in their areas. A very difficult administrative problem will arise. Ordinary ratepayers in local government areas will find it more difficult to gain equity than will the rather larger councils which have access to that kind of revenue.

I was rather startled at Question Time today, when Senator Chaney addressed a question to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, about Rothwells Ltd in Perth, that the Minister had nothing to say except that he really thought everything would be all right as far as Rothwells in Western Australia was concerned and that it was likely that his only interest would be stirred in this matter in the event of there being a collapse of Rothwells and the Government of Western Australia being called upon to contribute money to beef up Rothwells bank. Many senators have followed this matter with a great deal of interest. I see tonight that things have come to a head in that we have now heard that the stock exchange has suspended trading in the shares of Rothwells Ltd. I heard tonight that the Chairman of the National Securities and Exchange Commission (NCSC), Mr Bosch, is calling for audited statements to be presented as quickly as possible so that the true financial situation of Rothwells bank can be assessed in the interests of the shareholders and, presumably, the depositors as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, it is not a bank. Its dealing licence was withdrawn last year. It continues to call itself a bank, but it is not a bank.

—Senator Stone is absolutely right. The securities dealing licence was withdrawn last year. Since Senator Stone has drawn me to the subject, I will continue to talk about it because obviously it is relevant to the Bill that is before us. Quite clearly, if the Commonwealth is making grants to the States and the State governments are using those funds to prop up business enterprises in their own areas of concern, the Commonwealth has a direct interest in the outcome of those events.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be as well to look at the background to the Rothwells development over the last 12 months. Honourable senators will recall that immediately following the stock exchange crash of 19 October last year Rothwells in Perth was drawn into considerable difficulty. A bailing out operation was set up by various millionaires in Perth-Mr Holmes a Court and Mr Bond, amongst others-in order to safeguard Rothwells organisation. Those changes, which involved real estate purchases from Rothwells, properties being sold, leasing back, and so on, occurred on 26 October last year. The next day the Government of Western Australia gave a guarantee of $150m of taxpayers' money as an endorsement on a stand-by bill in order to safeguard the funding of Rothwells. At that time the State Superannuation Board in Western Australia appointed a board member to sit on the board of Rothwells. There were certain arrangements about fees which would accrue to the Government. The first question that arises is whether a government should be involved in entrepreneurial activity such as receiving fees for guarantees and so on. Leaving aside that question, the question then arises as to what were the motives of the Government of Western Australia in getting involved in the first place?

On 30 November the then Premier, Mr Burke, was noted in the press as saying that shire councils and charities would have lost $60m or $70m had Rothwells crashed and that that was a justification for State Government activity. That might be so, but it would be interesting to know why it was that those charities and those State government and shire council bodies put their money in Rothwells in the first place. That question has not been answered, as I understand it. On 23 December last year, a couple of days before Christmas, Mr Connell, the head of Rothwells, got his Christmas present when the NCSC withdrew his securities dealer's licence for Rothwells. Consequently, it has not been able to operate in that condition.

On 7 March this year a company controlled by Mr Connell lent $30,000 to the head of the Western Australian State Superannuation Board, Mr Brush, on the security of an insurance claim in which apparently it had been involved in 1985. A very close connection with Rothwells and the Government of Western Australia was indicated in that regard. On 16 July there then developed a new phase in the operations of Rothwells. We saw the Government, desperately, for electoral purposes, try to remove itself from its guarantee of $150m for Connell to get out of the Rothwells bank. It did this in a rather curious way. The guarantee had to be got rid of and the Government had to remove itself from its possible obligation in the event of Rothwells going bust. Apparently, the Bond Corporation approached the Government and came up with a deal for the establishment of a petrochemical works near Kwinana in Western Australia, just south of Perth.

This is a rather interesting exercise. I will not bore the Senate with all the details, but the essence of it is this: Mr Connell, who was then the head of the Rothwells organisation, would be forced and financed, by both the Bond organisation and the Government, to take over certain debts of Rothwells totalling $350m, in compensation for which he would receive shares in a company called Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd. The acronym by which it goes is PICL. One cannot imagine the Western Australian Government being in a worse pickle than it is over this matter. This company, Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd, apparently has relatively little in the way of assets. In fact, if we look at its balance sheet we find that it has no tangible assets; all its assets are described as intangible. By resolution of the board of the company, all the expenditure of the company is built up on the balance sheet as an intangible asset and has absolutely no worth. Needless to say, the company has achieved nothing in terms of getting operational.

The Government of Western Australia has committed $175m to that company so that it will-as it discloses as its objective-set up a petrochemical works in Kwinana. I point out to the Senate that that, together with another $225m from the Bond organisation, is mostly going in two directions. First and foremost, $350m is going to Mr Connell to buy back debts from the Rothwells bank. Of course, he will then have these debts, which are virtually worthless. Another $50m will be paid to the other partner in the company, Mr Dallas Dempster, a businessman from Perth, for his shares in Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd, which obviously have very little value. It will enable him to spend that $50m on his other major investment, the Burswood Casino in Perth.

In order to try to fill this out a little, I turn to the balance sheet of Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd. I have here the report of the directors for the year ended 30 June 1988, and I find in the annual report, as filed with the Corporate Affairs Commission in Perth, that the net profit of the company during the year after provision for income tax was nil. Of course no dividends were paid to any shareholders, and the review of operations for the year indicates that the project continued as a result of an acceptable feasibility study concerning some objective in establishing the Kwinana site. I find from the figures in the balance sheet that apart from this no profit situation, total shareholder equity is described as being $500,000. That might be a tremendous amount of money, but if we look down the list we find an item described as property, plant and equipment, to the value of $262,000. Then, the next item is an intangible asset of $21.5m. Of course we then have the corresponding liability, which presumably is borrowings from the State Government and other sources in Western Australia.

So we have this company with an intangible asset made up, as I say, of accumulated expenditure on what is non-recoverable assets, of something like $21m. Yet the Government of Western Australia has seen fit to invest $175m in this company and it has said, as some sort of justification, `Well, Mr Bond has come along as part of the deal with another $225m'. This is absolutely amazing. It must be one of the greatest financial mirror tricks of all time. How can someone who is supposed to be a very important businessman in this country, Mr Bond, be convinced to put in over $200m, and how can the Western Australian Government be convinced to put in nearly another $200m, for something that is not worth a cracker?

I suppose there has to be some other story behind all of this. We find various press references to a valuation of this company having been done. Apparently, this valuation was carried out by the First Boston Bank in the United States. It came up with a valuation of something like $400m. We have not seen that valuation. The Government of Western Australia has not disclosed it or made it public in any way, and of course that is the major complaint of all the people involved in this matter. Nobody really knows anything about what is going on with Rothwells because there is no proper accountability of that show. It is hard to comment on the First Boston Bank valuation, but let us try to find out what are the assets of Petrochemical Industries. It has a block of land at Kwinana. Honourable senators will remember that I mentioned that around $260,000 had been invested in land, and presumably that is the land. The second asset is a contract to buy gas from the State Energy Commission of Western Australia. I suppose that is some sort of asset, but we do not know what the price of the gas is going to be. We have no way of assessing what the profitability from the buying of that gas by such a petrochemical company might be. It would be interesting, therefore, to get hold of the Government's valuation from the First Boston Bank to find out what that is all about.

There is a further contract-it is described as a contract-with Mitsubishi to buy the entire plastic feed stock supplied by Petrochemical Industries. I do not know what it is that is being produced, and we do not know whether that is a binding agreement on Mitsubishi or just a few scribbles on a piece of paper. It would be very useful if that kind of information were produced for public viewing so that we could properly assess what is happening with this company. There is a further contract, of course, to build a plant, the cost of which is described as being something like $800m. As far as we know, that money would be coming from the First Boston Bank.

But we still have the question of why this company is so valuable to Mr Bond and the Western Australian Government that they would put in, collectively, $400m at this point in time when its only assets are the ones I have just described and which do not show on the balance sheet any value whatsoever. Of course, as I have pointed out, the only asset on the balance sheet of any apparent worth is worth nothing. This has to be one of the greatest financial question marks of all times. This Senate should be demanding, as should the Minister for Finance be demanding, that the Western Australian Government provide some accountability concerning this matter because quite obviously taxpayers' money is at risk. We have seen today that trading in Rothwells shares has been suspended on the Stock Exchange. We have seen in the last day Mr Connell, the former Chairman of Rothwells, resign from office. We have seen, on top of the $150m worth of guarantee that I mentioned earlier in the piece that occurred back in October last year, a further $75m injected into Rothwells yesterday. This follows a run on the bank last week. What is more, we have seen a lot of jiggery-pokery with a $10m bill from the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia that apparently could not be met by Rothwells last week and which involved some kind of baling out operation by other parts of Western Australia Inc.

There are so many unanswered questions associated with this matter that most urgent action has to be taken by the Hawke- Keating Government, and in particular by the Minister for Finance. They must demand answers from the Western Australian Government as to what is going on. As Mr Bosch, the Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission, said tonight, there must be an accounting, there must be a proper audit conducted of the affairs of Rothwells so that we can understand exactly what the liability of the people of Western Australia is. If an enormous amount of money is at risk in this complicated set of deals, the Government should be taking action to ensure that State revenue grants to the Government of Western Australia are restricted until it gets its affairs in order. That would appear to me to be appropriate action by the Federal Government-this Government that claims to have so much integrity in the way it conducts its affairs. It is supposed to be full of economic brains and yet it allows a financial shambles of this order to develop under its own nose.

Of course we have a Labor Government here in Canberra holding sway over the Parliament and its sister Government in Western Australia, and we know that the Minister for Finance is a senator elected on the Australian Labor Party ticket in Western Australia. Who better to undertake such an important study and make sure that the Government of Western Australia is made accountable for its actions and for its funding to the people of Western Australia than Senator Walsh, who is the leading and most senior member of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government from Western Australia? This is not just a mere duty that he should perform on behalf of all the people of Australia. He has an obligation to put pressure on his colleagues who run the Government of Western Australia to find out exactly what is going on with Western Australia Inc. and to ensure that they make a proper accounting not only to the people of the State of Western Australia but to the Commonwealth of Australia as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation, as Senator Messner may well have said before I came into the chamber, is part of the Government's great cost cutting program; its expenditure cutting program. It is also a buck-passing exercise as far as real expenditure cuts are concerned because in limiting funding to the States it passes on the responsibility for making cuts in the areas of health, housing and education in particular to State governments. It implements the arrangements agreed to at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting in May in relation to the Commonwealth's general purpose payments to the States. If I have time I will go in a little more detail into the shambles that those Premiers Conferences are turning into as far as Commonwealth Grants Commission recommendations are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, the payments made under this States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988, along with general purpose capital assistance provided for under the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill, have a major impact on the spending and borrowing of State governments. That means that they have a major impact on levies, costs and charges passed on to the consumer in areas which are under the jurisdiction of State governments. People are being forced to bear Federal Government costing cuts because the State government is not exercising a great deal of restraint. It cannot afford, in many cases, to exercise restraint in those vulnerable areas of education, housing and health care.

This is particularly bad when one considers that the level of assistance provided in the Bill before us tonight in fact involves a reduction of some $650m against the Forward Estimates at the time of the Premiers Conference. That is a statement-an admission if you like-that was made in the second reading speech of the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding). He did not seem to be particularly fussed by it, but I think it is a fairly appalling indictment of a government that preaches expenditure restraint and then forces it onto State governments and passes the buck in doing so. On the Government's own figures, general purpose payments to the States and the Northern Territory are estimated to be down by 4.6 per cent in real terms on top of a reduction of a little more than 5 per cent in the last financial year.
The Government proudly asserts in the Minister's second reading speech that these cuts:
. . . contributed toward the fiscal restraint exercised by the State and Local Government sector in 1987-88 . . .

and furthermore goes on in that second reading speech to welcome the restraint. One needs to ask, first of all, whether there was a significant amount of restraint by the States; whether they did not simply choose to raise the extra money, as I said a moment ago, by increasing charges around the place. Or, if they did exercise restraint, what cost was there to provision of services in the areas of health, education and housing, and who was affected by that? One can bet one's life that they were not the sorts of people whom Senator Messner was talking about, the ones who can afford to contribute $200m to get a mate out of trouble. Those people were not affected by any State restraint, if it was exercised, nor were they likely to be particularly affected by increased charges imposed by State governments to make up the shortfall.

The Government itself has argued that it is important that all levels of government restrain their spending and borrowing in order to restrain domestic demand, reduce the call on domestic savings and arrest the build-up in foreign debt. When will the Government do something about the 50 per cent or more of the foreign debt which is run up by the private sector? It is no good simply hitting the States and hoping they will not borrow. This Government continues to encourage foreign borrowings by the private sector by continuing to permit tax concessions, such as negative gearing, regardless of whether the money is borrowed for expansion from the domestic market or from the foreign market.

The Opposition's attitude to this restraint-and I use the word loosely-by the Federal Government is quite interesting. If we have a look at the speech made by Mr Peacock in another place last month, we find him saying:

I am not criticising the Government for the reductions in payments to the States. I am criticising the Government, however, for the hypocrisy it has shown in demanding spending restraint from all other levels of government while at the same time not matching the bid it asks the States to accept. I shall therefore be moving an amendment . . .
Part of that amendment-and I presume we will see it in this chamber-says:
(b) this Government has been found wanting in the need to bear its share of expenditure restraint by cutting its own direct expenditure, . . .

I have got news for Mr Peacock. In case he has not noticed, this Government has drastically cut expenditure in some areas and it has done it with the enthusiastic cooperation of every Opposition senator in this place. The Government has cut expenditure in health care provision, in public housing provision, in education and particularly in social welfare. It has done it both directly through legislation in this place and indirectly by cutting funding to the States. As I said, it got the support it needed to get the direct cuts through-that is, the cuts that were legislated in this Parliament-not from the Australian Democrats, but from the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia together.

If people want to check the Hansard records, they will find the information there. They will see that the Government delayed pension consumer price index increases just before Christmas in 1986 with the support of the Opposition. The Government cut ex-Service pension increases with the support of Opposition senators. The Government cut Austudy payments to 15-year-old students from low income families in their last two years of school, with the support of the Opposition. At the same time, it cut unemployment benefits for 16- and 17-year olds. The Government took action against-of all people-45-year-old widows. It put legislation before this chamber, which was supported by the Liberal and National Party senators in this place, that insisted that once a woman who was on widow's class B pension turned 45 and her youngest child turned 16, she was to come off the class B widow's pension and go onto unemployment benefits or look for a job. Imagine what that did for the self-esteem of many of those women, because the jobs are simply not out there. The same businessmen-and I use the word advisedly-who are pressing this Government to cut back on social welfare expenditure are the very ones who will not take on a 45-year-old woman who has been out of the work force raising a family for 20 or so years, because they give no credit to the managerial and personnel skills, much less the budgeting skills, that a woman in that position has developed. Mr Peacock needs to look at the Senate Hansard and find out not only what action the Government has taken but also who helped the Government get that legislation through. In fact, Mr Peacock goes on to say that, in the Government's moves:
They forget about Australians and they forget about those struggling.
`They' meaning the Government. He says:
They just look after themselves and look after their mates.

Certainly, as I mentioned earlier, the Government has not done much to stop the borrowing practices and the tax write-offs of some of the biggest companies in the country, which are allowing these people to pay zero cents in the dollar in tax each year. If Mr Peacock does not think that ordinary Australians and others who are struggling have suffered, he had better look at the Hansard records of what has gone through in this place. He might also like to consult a few reports that have come down about the social and economic inequities that exist in this country. I will make it easy for him and give him some examples. The number of Australians living below the poverty line has more than doubled since the mid-1970s. It now exceeds two million, of whom a great number are children. The number of people unemployed for more than a year has increased seven times since the mid-1970s. The number of people waiting for public housing has more than doubled-this, despite the fact that the Government allowed a return of a negative gearing capacity for private investment in rental property on the somewhat laughable assertion that it would encourage wealthy investors to provide rental housing for those in poverty. Over the same period, however, Australia's gross domestic product has increased per capita by about 15 per cent in real terms. In other words, although Australia has become a much richer country, the number of people living in poverty has risen considerably.

There are people who would argue that this has fallen most heavily on middle Australia. It certainly has impacted dramatically on that sector. But low income people have not, as it has sometimes been asserted, been protected from the decline in living standards which middle Australia has experienced over the last few years. The May economic statement indicated that there are a great number of sole parents and young unemployed people, for example, whose disposable income has been reduced by as much as 25 per cent.

By contrast, personal wealth in this country has exploded during the past two years at a rate and to levels practically unknown previously. Certainly, until October of last year share speculation was mostly responsible. But since then the major avenue for rapid increases in wealth has been in the property market. There are now between 40,000 and 50,000 millionaires in Australia. The top one per cent of adult Australians hold about a quarter of all private wealth. The top 10 per cent of adult Australians hold more than 60 per cent of the wealth of this country. Mr Peacock, in a speech to the House on 13 October this year, made a passing reference to a comment by Senator Walsh that we are on the road to Argentina. I would suggest that, if this were a South American country, that disparity in the distribution of wealth would be producing a revolution somewhere. The difficulty is that very few people know about the inequities in the distribution of wealth. As I said, the top 10 per cent of adult Australians hold more than 60 per cent of the wealth of this country, while two million people, including 600,000 children, live below the poverty line.

These inequalities in access to disposable income show up in things like decreased access to housing for middle and low income earners. Middle income earners are finding it increasingly difficult to own their own homes because of the rising costs of land and housing and of money. Low income earners simply cannot get access to housing at all. We have, too, a highly inequitable taxation system which favours companies against pay as you earn taxpayers. The Government's 1985 tax reform package favoured high income earners, whose marginal tax rates were slashed from 60c to 49c in the dollar, but did not provide similar sorts of benefits to average and low income earners. They got very little tax relief from that year's tax reform package. The tax rate for companies this year was reduced in the Federal Budget from 49c to 39c in the dollar-on the same day that Alan Bond's company posted a record profit of $354m on which it was announced that it had calculated a tax liability of $4m, a little over 1c in the dollar. It turned out that Alan Bond had over-estimated. An article in the Australian Financial Review last week indicated that he is going to pay no tax at all. There are not too many pensioners in this country who are earning a little extra income who can get away with paying no cents in the dollar on their earnings.

We are looking at falling real wages for low and middle income earners at the same time as top executives are increasing their income in leaps and bounds. It is not always easy to find out what senior company executives are getting but if one looks at the banking sector, a sector that is constantly claiming that it must push up interest rates and increase its charges on services provided to its depositors, we discover that very little restraint has been exercised at the top end.

The annual report of Westpac Banking Corporation, released in January of this year, showed that four of its chief executives earned more than $1.5m in salary packages in 1987, another eight more than $500,000 and 97 senior staff more than $90,000. Westpac says, `It is not fair of you to quote the fact that four of our executives earned $1.5m'-or were paid $1.5m; that is probably a better way of expressing it-`in 1987. Those people are our Westpac people in Japan and America. We have to buy them houses and cars and give them decent wage packages. When you convert that to Australian dollars, because of the exchange rate you get $1.5m. We know it sounds a lot, but it is not, really'. That argument does not wash with me and I hope that it does not wash with too many other people. What Westpac is saying is, `We are putting increased charges on servicing accounts and demanding that interest rates go up so that ordinary Australians can subsidise the high salaries of executives in the United States and Japan'.

Low income earners and social security recipients are the fall guys of this Government's alleged expenditure restraint package. They are facing the problems of falling incomes, higher housing costs, the unavailability of public housing and rising prices for basic food and clothing and are watching salaries, services and benefits blow out at the other end of the market. Whilst some people are employed on massive salaries, others-some 600,000 of them-are on unemployment benefits and almost 60 per cent of them have been unemployed for six months or more. A decade ago long term unemployment was restricted to 20 per cent-not 60 per cent-of the unemployed. So much for the Government's equity program. So much for the Government's much vaunted restraint, a restraint which is supposed to be keeping down the foreign debt by cutting the disposable income of middle and low income earners, but which is doing nothing to limit the contribution to the foreign debt that is made by companies which are paying less than a cent in the dollar in tax. There are other ways of balancing budgets than by simply slicing money and services to low income earners. We could do a little to raise a little more from those who can afford it, and that means some of the biggest companies in this country.

One of the other major problems that is facing this Government and State governments with regard to expenditure cuts has been incorporated in this piece of legislation, I think for the first time. The States Grants (General Revenue) Bill applies for a single year rather than a triennium. One wonders exactly how much planning State governments can do on annual funding when they are used to triennial funding. Indeed, one wonders, even if they had not been used to it, how they would cope with cuts of this magnitude when they had applied for a single year and there was a promise of more to come.
The Minister concluded his second reading speech by saying:
The Bill forms an important part of the Commonwealth's endeavours to continue public sector restraint at all levels of government.

As I mentioned earlier, this was supported by the Opposition. There is no word here about private sector restraint; there is no word here about increasing revenue from sources that are available to the Government; and there is no word here about proposals by the Government in the near future to make some impact on loss of revenue caused by tax concessions, which are not doing what they were originally intended to do, which are not increasing productivity, which are not increasing employment, but which instead are increasing our foreign debt and drastically reducing the amount of revenue the Government can glean from alleged taxpayers in order to support those who are badly off.

I said a little while ago that I wanted to make some comments about the way in which the Government goes into the general revenue grants program. I think it is worth while looking at the history of this. Since the early 1980s the Commonwealth Grants Commission has been given the task of assessing appropriate per capita revenue-sharing relativities to apply to the distribution of general revenue grants among the six States. It has done this allegedly to ensure that a fair distribution reflecting the principle of fiscal equalisation-I use the Government's own term-is applied to the States. As far as we know, to date the Commonwealth Grants Commission has carried out its relativities review on a three-year basis and has done it relatively efficiently.

However, it has increasingly been the case under both this Government and the previous Government that, where the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission have been wholly or substantially adopted, certain phasing-in adjustments have been included and implemented at the Premiers Conference in order to cushion the move to new relativities by some of the losing States. So we get this transfer through the phasing-in process from the so-called winning States to the losing States. Even though the Commission's recommendations have been formally adopted, given the cut in the level of general revenue funding, some States have had to be given special revenue assistance under the terms of the guarantee by the Government that no State would have a fall in its nominal funding. What is more, as I have said, the funds used to meet this guarantee have been transferred from the so-called winning States and, as has happened in the past, the effect of this guarantee has been to alter effectively the recommendations of the Commission, which makes one wonder why we have the Commission going through this futile exercise, assessing relativities, looking at equalisation and coming up with recommendations that will then have the thimble and pea trick applied to them as money is transferred from the so-called winners to the so-called losers. What, one wonders, is the point?

This is made even more ludicrous when we consider the matter I raised earlier; that is, that no arrangements have been determined as of this year for next year or the following year. So the triennial mode has been turned into an annual system making it increasingly difficult for the States to undertake forward planning. I think this is a problem when one considers how the States are dealing with the cuts. This is the third consecutive year in which real cuts have been applied to the assistance the Federal Government provides to the States, and we are seeing State governments increasingly responding by cutting capital expenditure. Now that is fine in the short term, but what sort of problems will occur if they continue to cope with this new system by cutting capital expenditure? We will see a massive problem arising, I suspect in the shorter future rather than the longer future, as far as the adequacy of the provision and maintenance of Australia's public infrastructure is concerned.

Are we looking at a time when our universities, our public hospitals and our state schools will fall into disrepair because State governments have slashed capital expenditure in an attempt to make do with the diminishing amount of money that the Federal Government is giving them by way of general grants? I think this concern is magnified by the fact that the Government is also slashing general purpose and hospital payments to the States by 4.9 per cent this year on top of a 4.8 per cent cut in 1987-88 and a further previous cut of 1.1 per cent. One wonders just how State governments will manage without totally privatising the public hospital sector, the public school sector and the public housing sector.

Indeed, suggestions are now being made in some States, including my own, that State governments should move out of the area of providing public housing and hand it all over to the private sector, and whatever subsidies are provided to the State governments are handed to the private sector. Certainly the State Government in South Australia is doing an excellent de facto job of privatising the state school system. As a response to the limited amount of funding now being handed over to it by the Federal Government, it has cut expenditure on the provision of services to state schools, and to most parents it is not worthwhile sending their children to a state school. No matter how good the teaching may be, no matter how well intentioned the staff may be, the school's resources are so limited that they simply cannot adequately cope with the needs of the students, much less the demands of the students.

This Federal Government, through these reduced grants, is effectively forcing State governments to privatise those areas where currently the public sector is providing some sort of competition for the private sector. It is doing so, with the full cooperation of Liberal and National party senators in this place, at the same time as it is further cutting benefits to low income earners as individuals and to low income earning families. I say to Labor Party senators that, if they bother to look at themselves in the mirror, they must wonder why they have not got `C' for Conservative branded on their foreheads. They are implementing the sort of legislation that a future conservative government would dearly love to implement but could not get past a Labor opposition, as the Fraser Government could not get some of these proposals through the Labor Opposition in 1981-82. When Labor is in opposition it has some concern for its traditional supporters. When it is in government it does what Mr Peacock alleged on 13 October in another place that it did. It looks after its mates and forgets middle and low income Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988 in relation to which, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:

(a) this government's prospective 1988-89 budget surplus is mostly based on increased taxation, and over 70 per cent of the expenditure cuts in budget outlays comes from reduced payments to state governments;
(b) this government has been found wanting in the need to bear its share of expenditure restraint by cutting its own direct expenditure; and

(c) the arrangements outlined in the Bill reflect policies that discourage the incentive to invest and work productively and therefore facilitate the restructuring of the Australian economy to address the nation's net foreign debt of some $88 billion''.

The Bill before the Senate tonight is largely based on the May Premiers Conference which will once again see my own State of Tasmania facing further funding cuts. Despite promises by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in July of last year that there would be no further cuts to Tasmania my State has lost nearly $30m from its revenue grant, which is equal to a real cut of 5.2 per cent over the past 12 months. While this Federal Government has increased its overseas borrowing limit, the State governments are not permitted to make any overseas borrowings. The Federal Government has more than doubled its global limit on borrowings while reducing the States' limit by 11.2 per cent. The Federal Government has increased the limit on borrowings for its own authorities by $1,452m. This is almost entirely due to a special component of $1,450m for the aviation sector. Although I do not doubt that additional borrowings were needed to meet major fleet re-equipment and expansion requirements for Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines and related airport infrastructure, it seems that this is at the expense of hospitals and schools. Of course, the aviation industry makes a substantial contribution to the economy in Australia, but this example-where one of the Commonwealth's authorities gains precedence over the provision of essential public services-is testimony, I believe, to the benefits of privatisation of such bodies.

The Premier of my State of Tasmania, Mr Gray, had been promised by the Prime Minister that funding would not be cut to the State and naturally plans were made by the State Government on the basis of continued funding. To face funding cuts in the light of plans having been set places a significant burden on any State government. I commend Robin Gray on his September budget which contained no tax increases for individual Tasmanians and substantial payroll tax cuts for small and medium sized businesses. The economic reality is that no State in Australia has more going for it than Tasmania. It has a wealth of resources in its people, agriculture, industry and natural resources. However, we are a sparsely populated State, facing diseconomies of scale in the provision of essential services. The State's financial realities are shaped largely by the level of funding received from the Federal Government. In 1981-82, 91 per cent of the State's receipts for works and services came from Canberra. This year the equivalent figure is 32 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Senator Walsh is quite right. It is a shame. He will have to take much of the responsibility for that tremendous decrease. Taking recurrent and capital receipts together, total Commonwealth payments have fallen from 63 per cent of State consolidated fund receipts to 48 per cent. The Commonwealth has also reduced its own capital works expenditure in Tasmania. As a result of the Federal Budget, the State will receive only 0.7 per cent of the entire Commonwealth capital works program budget for 1988-89 even though when he signed away $277m in 1984 for the Franklin Dam compensation, Prime Minister Hawke agreed not to make corresponding reductions in payments to Tasmania, but again the State appears to be suffering.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems ironical that as a quirk of our fiscal arrangements it is the States that provide the majority of services to Australians, such as schools and hospitals, police forces to ensure law and order, the maintenance of roads and ports and the provision of welfare services, yet despite the magnitude of these services the States are starved of the funds required to fulfil their obligations. While the States face continued demands for services from the public, the Federal Government is imposing financial constraints on State governments which forces them to make cuts in spending in some areas. TALK.START.PARA: —When one considers the size of Tasmania and its economy one will realise that a loss of $440m-as revealed in that table-makes a considerable difference to the level of services provided by the Government and the State's economy in general. This money would have meant approximately $1,000 extra for every man, woman and child in the State. Another way of looking at this amount of money and its impact on the Tasmanian economy is to realise that in theory approximately $1m produces something like 40 jobs. Therefore, this amount of money would have been sufficient to provide jobs for just about all of the 17,000 unemployed persons in Tasmania. The cut to Tasmania in recurrent funding of $150m has meant that the State Government has had to increase taxes to raise an additional $70m. This leaves a shortfall of approximately $80m which the State has had to absorb. This has been achieved to some extent by the Government's policy to reduce the Tasmanian Public Service. Since gaining power in 1982, the Government has succeeded in reducing the work force of the State service by 7 per cent. Nevertheless, the impact of the reduced funding has been felt throughout the State.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the Tasmanian Government's attempts to become more self-sufficient and less dependent on the economic development of other States of the nation, it is continually thwarted by increasing interference by the Federal Government. Control is becoming centralised in Australia as the Federal Government continues its surreptitious gathering of power. In nearly every conceivable area of policy making, State governments face constraints imposed by the Federal Government, either by financial or legal limitations. The irony of the situation is that it is not the Federal politicians who have gained the benefit of the aggregation of powers; the Commonwealth senior public servants are the ones who have managed to create their own kingdoms and develop their own power bases. The resounding decision by the people of Australia earlier this year at the referendum stands as testimony to the fact that the public is satisfied with the Constitution and its arrangements. It is improper for the Federal Government to continue to usurp the mandate of the public by encroaching power from the States, particularly by imposing fiscal or financial constraints on the States.

Another hypocrisy of the present Federal Budget and States grants is that the Federal Government has insisted that the States curb their spending and exercise constraint while the Federal Government increases its own limit on borrowing. All of the States were cajoled into accepting a freeze in their grants and to show constraint. If the Federal Government had been able to exercise the restraint as it is advocating the States should do, the Federal Budget surplus may have been closer to $12m not $5m. Considering the burden of the provision of services in the Commonwealth it appears inequitable that the States should be asked to show constraint without the Federal Government doing so at the same rate.

The Commonwealth Public Service employs large numbers of people in areas that duplicate State service areas. When it is the State which provides the service it seems ironical that it is asked to provide services with less funding with the inevitability of reduced or lower quality services. Besides the more obvious reduction of financial support from the Federal Government there has also been a reduction in Commonwealth funds provided in terms of services to our State.

For example, the following Commonwealth departments and bodies have been closed recently in Tasmania: the Promotion Australia Office; the regional office of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation; the Australian Federal Police office in Launceston; the Telecom Australia office at Burnie with a loss of 42 jobs; and the office of the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations. The office dealing with the diesel fuel rebate payments has been transferred from Hobart to South Australia. There has been a transfer of the office looking after the payments of pharmaceutical benefits from Hobart to Victoria. In the latter case that has resulted in increased delays of payments to pharmaceutical chemists in my State, contrary to the arrangements which had been promised by the Federal Government. It is proposed to cut back on work in the Ant- arctic Division. Already the Government has removed the fire service at Wynyard and threatened removal from Launceston and Hobart airports. It announced that on 9 August 1988 the Department of Social Security office would be reduced with a loss of 60 to 70 jobs.

It appears that the State Grants (General Revenue) Bill required some extra attention in its drafting to eliminate some of its problems. Allow me to highlight a couple of the more glaring definitional problems associated with this Bill. Excuse me if I go through some of the definitions because I think this will highlight some of the problems I wish to raise. The Bill's definition of `borrowing' has the same meaning as in the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Act 1987. In the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Act 1987 section 3 (1) states:
In this Act:
``Body'' has the same meaning as in the Levy Act;
``Borrowing'' includes the raising of money by dealing in securities;
``Levy Act'' means the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 . . .

The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 3 (1) states that a body means a body referred to in the schedule. Here is the rub. This schedule sets out a list of bodies to which the Act pertains. These include: Aussat Pty Ltd; the Australian National Airlines Commission; the Australian National Railways Commission; the Australian Postal Commission; the Australian Trade Commission; the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission; the Health Insurance Commission; Overseas Telecommunications Commission Australia; and Qantas Airways Ltd. It is important to take this all into consideration because it provides the basis for the current Bill under consideration. The significant factor is that all of these bodies are Commonwealth or national institutions. The States Grants (General Revenue) Bill under consideration is concerned with Commonwealth bodies which includes this list in the schedule. The borrowing definition does not cover borrowing from States and, consequently in this light, Tasmanian global borrowing allocations would become meaningless.

Clause 7 (1) (a) of the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill is of major concern to all Tasmanians and other Australians as it effects the level of borrowings any State may undertake. Clause 7 (1) states that:
Financial assistance to which a State is entitled under this Act in relation to the grant year is granted on the following conditions:
(a) that the State will not allow the sum of its new borrowings and the new borrowings of the State's instrumentalities to exceed the global borrowing limit for the State . . .
The Bill interprets `new borrowing' as being:
. . . an amount of a borrowing that is received in the grant year but does not include an amount of a borrowing for the purpose of refinancing debt outstanding on 30 June 1988;

An implication of this is that it does not preclude the loan component of general purpose capital assistance from being classified as new borrowings. Therefore, the global borrowing limit will be made up of both general purpose capital assistance Loan Council borrowings and global borrowings. This has not previously been the situation. The effect of the proposed interpretation is that the level of actual global borrowings will be reduced. For example, in the case of Tasmania the global borrowing limit is $171m. The State's ability to borrow has already been reduced by $10.6m, at 11.2 per cent cut, from last year and as a State we cannot afford to lose any more borrowing power.

It is estimated that the Loan Council borrowings component of the general purpose capital funds for 1988-89 will be $27.7m. If the Bill is interpreted so as to classify the loan component of the general purpose capital assistance as new borrowings, it will have the effect of reducing the real global borrowing limit to $143.3m. In order to ensure that the full global borrowing limit is maintained the interpretation of the Bill needs to to be altered so that general purpose capital assistance is excluded from global borrowings.
Another unclear interpretation concerns the definition of State instrumentality. The Bill proposes that a State instrumentality includes:
(b) a body corporate that is an instrumentality of the State;

This raises the important question as to whether this definition includes State banks and financial institutions of the State. If these institutions are included, this Bill effectively subverts the intentions of the Loan Council. Keeping in mind the reservations about the shift in the delicate Federal balance between Canberra and the States, the coalition does not oppose the Bill. But, it is certainly concerned about the impact that these definitional changes will have on the particular States and for that reason the Opposition has moved that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this evening a very important piece of legislation, that is, the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988. This Bill provides for something like 15 per cent of the total outlays from the Commonwealth Budget; so it is not a small matter. It is notable and indeed, I think, the Opposition second reading amendment, certainly implicitly if not explicitly, points out that in this area the Commonwealth Government has this year imposed a significant cut in real terms in the funding available to the States. It is a cut which, if I may say so, is rather out of proportion with what the Commonwealth has failed to do in relation to its own spending programs. There has been a cut of 4.6 per cent in real terms in general purpose payments to the States imposed this year, that is in the general revenue assistance provided by this Bill plus the general purpose capital payments which are made available through the Commonwealth Budget or through the global borrowings limits. However, the Bill does more than that, and I want to focus my remarks tonight on some particular aspects of the legislation which are highly detrimental to my own State of Queensland. I make no apology for doing that. I would do the same if there were as discriminatory an approach being imposed on any other State, but as it happens my own State is involved in this particular case.
