TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister and the Senate. The relevant clause of the Bill bearing upon these events is clause 7. The explanatory memorandum, in reference to clause 7, reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: This Clause makes the payment of financial assistance under the Bill conditional upon a State observing the global borrowing limit proposed by the Commonwealth at the 1988 meeting of the Australian Loan Council.
The explanatory note goes on to say:
Sub-clause (1) (b) provides that, if he-
that is, the Treasurer-
determines that a State has breached those limits during 1988-89, the Treasurer may reduce payments of financial assistance to that State by an amount up to the excess borrowing.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have reduced the States', but increased their own.

—As Senator Watson quite properly interpolates, we have here a situation where the Commonwealth is significantly reducing the global borrowing limits for all the States, and particularly, as I pointed out, in a totally discriminatory manner-there can be no argument about this-for Queensland, while at the same time tripling its own borrowing limit. It is notable, however, that clause 7 subclause (1) of the Bill, to which I just referred, is not framed in terms of Queensland alone. It is in fact framed-as of course it needs to be, for constitutional reasons I think-in terms of all States or any State; so that all States are under this particular legislative harrow which the Treasurer has introduced in this Bill. Some may say that that in itself does not matter too much because in the case of those other five States the amounts by which their borrowing limits have been reduced average-and I shall not weary the Senate by going through them State by State-only a reduction of 7.7 per cent and in the times we live in perhaps that can be borne.

SPEECH.PARA: We are really talking, in practice if not in theory, about Queensland, which, of course, has had its borrowing limit reduced by 31.7 per cent, and that is in money terms. The figure, of course, is greater than that in real terms if one allows for a degree of inflation between the two years. It is to be noted, as I understand it, that this legislation including this particular draconian clause has been introduced by the Treasurer into the House of Representatives without any prior consultation with any State government; certainly not with the Government of Queensland, the State most likely to be affected by this provision, but in any case not with other State governments either so far as I am aware. I also understand that a number of States, including but not only Queensland, have expressed concern about the provision itself and in particular the sheer lack of courtesy involved on the part of the Treasurer and his Department in proceeding in that manner.

To look back a little, borrowings of the kind which this particular clause relates to used to be made-I suppose technically in some sense they still are made-under the Gentlemen's Agreement, or have been since 1936 at least, and it is certainly true that unlike borrowings under the Financial Agreement, borrowings under the Gentlemen's Agreement did not carry any mandatory provisions so far as the States were concerned. That is to say, agreements were made between the Commonwealth and the States but it was technically at least open to the States to breach those agreements, and indeed there have been past occasions when they did. The question, therefore, has always been whether, so to speak, in order to exert a degree of centralised control upon the borrowings of State governments or their instrumentalities in that manner, the Commonwealth would in fact resort to what used to be called the big stick in these matters and would threaten, and be prepared to carry out the threat, those errant States who did behave in that manner with a punishment in one form or another, usually by way of reduction of the financial assistance grants or whatever those grants have been called at various times over the years. They are now called the general revenue grants. That is exactly what we now have in clause 7 of this Bill.

I will come to the clause in question now. It is headed `State observance of global borrowing limit'. This is in a Bill which is ostensibly directed to the subject of `An Act to provide for grants to the States and the NT' and which in its short title is known as the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill. Clause 7, however, does not deal with that matter at all, at least not directly. It simply lays down a condition, as the title of the clause-`State observance of global borrowing limit'-implies. Subsection (1) says:
Financial assistance to which a State is entitled under this Act in relation to the grant year is granted on the following conditions:

(a) that the State will not allow the sum of the its new borrowings and the new borrowings of the State's instrumentalities to exceed the global borrowing limit for the State, being the amount specified in column 2 of the following Table opposite to the State.
Paragraph (b) reads:
. . . if, in the opinion of the Treasurer-
I shall come back to those words-

the global borrowing limit for the State has been exceeded, the Treasurer may reduce payment to the State under this Act by an amount equal to, or less than, the amount that the Treasurer determines to be the amount of the excess.

It is quite clear from the wording of that clause that in what used to be called when introduced in 1984 the voluntary arrangements, described as the so-called global borrowing limits program, the word `voluntary' is no longer appropriate.

We now have a quite naked element of compulsion entailed in these arrangements and contained in clause 7 of the Bill and, moreover, one which provides the Treasurer of the day with absolute discretion. As I indicated earlier, clause 7 (1) (b) simply states that if, in the opinion of the Treasurer, the global borrowing limit for the State has been exceeded, the Treasurer may do certain things to penalise the State by way of reducing the general revenue grants otherwise payable to it. It is very interesting, as my colleague Senator Watson said towards the end of his remarks, that some questions arise out of the phrasing of that paragraph. I hope that the Minister will address himself to these matters when he responds. There may be answers to the points I am about to make and which Senator Watson also briefly made. If so, I hope that the Minister will provide them.

The first point to note is that paragraph (a) of the clause says that the State `will not allow the sum of its new borrowings'-that is the State's new borrowings-`and the new borrowings of the State's instrumentalities . . .'. Under the Financial Agreement, the only way a State can actually make borrowings on its own account, other than temporary borrowings, is through borrowings which it has allocated to it by the Commonwealth when the Commonwealth borrows on account of the States. The States no longer borrow on their account. The Commonwealth makes all borrowings on behalf of the Commonwealth and the States and, having done so, allocates proportions of those borrowings in the books of the Commonwealth to each State and then the national debt sinking fund provisions begin to apply and so on.

Technically the clause says that its new borrowings-that is, the State's new borrowings-will be included for the purposes of this legislation in the global limits laid down by the Loan Council. That is another way of saying that what used to be called the works and housing or governmental borrowing program, which is actually borrowed by the Commonwealth and then allocated to the States, will be included in these limits. This may be incorrect, and I notice that in the definitions clause, clause 3 of the Bill, one sees:
``borrowing'' has the same meaning as in the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Act 1987.

I have not had time to consult that piece of legislation, and it may be that is the answer to the problem. If it is, I hope that the Minister will enlighten us accordingly; otherwise, there would seem to be a drafting problem.
Secondly, the clause goes on to refer to `new borrowings of the State's instrumentalities'. State instrumentalities are defined also in clause 3 as follows:
``State instrumentality'' includes:
(a) a semi-governmental or local authority of the State . . .
That is quite straightforward because borrowings by such bodies are certainly included in the global limits of the new arrangements. The second part of the definition reads:
(b) a body corporate that is an instrumentality of the State; and
(c) a trust of which the State is a trustee or a beneficiary.
I leave aside that last element as being, on its face at least, a wide catch-all category. But, concentrating on paragraph (b) of the definition, one sees:
a body corporate that is an instrumentality of the State.

To me that would appear to cover such bodies as State banks, State government insurance offices, and so on, as well as more normal bodies such as electricity commissions which might otherwise be called semi-governmental bodies.

On that basis it would seem that borrowings by any bodies of that type are included for the purposes of clause 7 (1) (a). But, so far as I am aware, borrowings by those bodies are not included in the resolutions of the Loan Council which govern the global borrowing limits. The global borrowing limits are laid down and agreed at the Loan Council meeting by way of resolution between the Commonwealth and the States. Indeed, the reason why we have this piece of legislation before us tonight is that, at the meeting in May, the Premier of Queensland refused to commit himself to the particular resolution in question. On the face of it, it appears-although again I shall wait to hear the Minister's response-that this clause is a major extension of the coverage of the term `borrowings' going well beyond the term `borrowings' as agreed in the resolution governing the global borrowing limits as agreed-at least between five Premiers and the Commonwealth-last May.

The Government of Queensland does not have a State bank, and I think that is the only State government that does not. If the State Bank of Victoria, which I imagine would be covered by the definition of a body corporate, that is an instrumentality of the State, were in need of capital-and banks these days, even State banks, are perennially in need of capital-if it were to make, let us say, a subordinate debt issue in the capital markets, that to my mind-and again I speak subject to the Minister's response-would appear to be a borrowing for the purpose of this legislation; although I repeat that it is not or has never previously been understood to be a borrowing for the purpose of the global borrowing limits resolution agreed to at the Loan Council meeting. Again, if a State Government Insurance Corporation-I shall refrain from following the line of discussion entered on earlier this evening by Senator Messner who was dealing with, among other things, one State government insurance corporation and its activities over recent months-were to make borrowings, including borrowings from banks, let alone borrowings from the market, for the purpose of conducting its activities, those borrowings also, as I read the Bill, would appear to be borrowings for the purpose of clause 7 (1) (a) of the Bill and would or could bring into play the powers that are exercisable by the Treasurer under paragraph (b) of clause 7.

I conclude by saying something about the quite blatant discrimination against the Government of Queensland by the Commonwealth Government which this whole episode reveals. As someone who has attended many Loan Council meetings over a very long time, I have never seen an action of this kind taken by the Commonwealth on such an outright and blatantly discriminatory basis. What were the reasons given for the Commonwealth's attack on Queensland last May, apart from the reasons not given-that is, the purely political reasons? Two reasons were given. The first was that Queensland was said to have an above average per capita borrowing requirement and this was in some sense judged to be unfair and therefore requiring a reduction in its borrowings in order to bring it back closer to the average. I will deal with that point in a moment. Secondly, it was said that Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures indicated that Queensland had a lower net financing requirement than any other State.

As to the first of those arguments, that Queensland had an above average per capita borrowing requirement, it has to be said, obviously, that Queensland was not the only State in that situation, almost by definition. Nevertheless, I am sure the Queensland authorities would agree that borrowing limits, if they are to apply, should do so on the basis of capital expenditure requirements. I think they would go on to argue that capital expenditure requirements are much more related to population growth, which is the factor governing the need for new investment in a State, than to overall population. As is a matter of record, Queensland is the fastest growing State in Australia in population terms, so it is hardly surprising that Queensland should have an above average per capita borrowing requirement. In contrast to the continual repetitions and dull statements to the contrary in this place by the Minister for Finance when in full flight at Question Time, on the basis of a con- venient Dorothy Dix question to him, Queensland is the fastest growing State in the Commonwealth. This Government has penalised it for that success.

The second reason given at that time by the Commonwealth for its discriminatory treatment of the State was, as I said earlier, that ABS figures indicated that Queensland had a lower net financing requirement than any other State. Let us think about that argument, if it can be dignified by the word `argument'. If one says that one State has a lower net financing requirement than any other State, that is another way of saying that Queensland's finances are in the best shape of any State in the Commonwealth. Again, that argument sits oddly with the perpetual, repetitious comments to the contrary emanating from the Minister for Finance time and again in this place during Question Time.

It must also be noted that in any case the ABS figures which are referred to are themselves subject to manifold deficiencies in some respects. For example Queensland is the only State which actually funds its own superannuation liabilities. As a consequence, it has a build-up in net financial assets which is not paralleled in any other State-a factor which enters into these comparisons. The fact that Queensland chooses to provide for its future superannuation liabilities, not merely unlike any other State but unlike the Commonwealth, should not surely be held to be a basis for penalising that State; rather it should be a basis for, if anything, congratulating it. In any case, as I have already indicated, such prudent financial behaviour hardly accords with the kind of picture of Queensland as a spendthrift and feckless financial State which the Minister for Finance time and again presents in the Senate.

It will be of great interest to hear what he says about the finances of Western Australia. I do not wish to enter into that debate and, in any case, time will not permit me to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988. I am pleased to follow Senator Stone, who addressed the matter of the 32 per cent reduction in Queensland's share of the global borrowing limits.
—So you are going to repeat it all.

—I certainly am not. I want to cover many other matters. As I said, Senator Stone did an absolutely admirable job in addressing the blatant attack on Queensland. Senator Stone is relatively new to the Senate. I have been here a little longer than he has, but every time we address the States grants Bills it becomes obvious that Queensland bears the brunt of Labor's attack. Queensland and Tasmania pay the heavy penalty of voting for conservative governments. Since 1983 Queensland has done very poorly in the distribution of the Commonwealth funds that this Bill cuts up. I often wonder what Queensland senators Black, Burns, Jones, Colston and Reynolds do, apart from throwing dorothy dixers to Senator Walsh and allowing him blatantly to attack Queensland and the Queensland economy. We should look at how Queensland is funded in the State revenue Bills.

All we ever get from Queensland senators is knocking, knocking, knocking.

SPEECH.PARA: No State has been worse affected than my State of Queensland. What was the Queensland Government offered at the last Premiers Conference? It is no wonder the Premier walked out in disgust. He did the only thing possible for him to do. He sought the same per capita level of financial assistance in real terms, full and immediate implementation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission recommendation, which would have meant about $40m extra for Queensland, and willingness on the part of the Commonwealth to share equitably the burden of financial restraint. But the Federal Government has shown absolutely no restraint. It has passed all the restraint onto the States, while the States offered a continuation of cooperation in the national economic interest. What did the Commonwealth Government give? A 4.2 per cent reduction in real terms in general revenue grants; only part implementation-about 50 per cent-of the Grants Commission's recommendations; and a 32 per cent reduction in the Queensland share of the global borrowing limit-meaning a reduction of $367m for Queensland.

What, we may ask, does this mean for Queensland? The failure to maintain the per capita level of assistance in real terms cost Queensland $112m; failure to implement fully Grants Commission recommendations, $17m; failure to maintain in dollar terms the same global borrowing limit, $367m; and failure to maintain the global limit in real per capita terms, another $66m. All up, Queensland lost $562m, or $220 for every man, woman and child in the State. That is the unjust and inequitable treatment that this Government has handed to the Queensland State Government. What have we heard from Senator Colston, Senator Jones, Senator Reynolds and Senator Black? Not a peep. Mt Olivet Hospital is seeking Federal funding to avert a financial catastrophe which would close more wards, reduce staff and restrict existing services.

The article says that a Mount Olivet spokesman said that the predicament was a direct result of the Federal Government's decision to withdraw its $670,000 annual grant. No wonder we see these types of articles running in the Queensland press. Hospitals are closing and old people's homes are not able to provide the services required. The Queensland Government has been forced into reducing some of the services it can offer. I say to the people of Queensland, when they complain about these reductions in services, that they should take their complaints to Government senators and Ministers. TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to get a public accounts committee up there?
—I think that Senator Maguire's interjections are becoming worse--

SPEECH.PARA: These are the sorts of things that I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate. It is high time that people became aware of this discrimination against the Queensland and Tasmanian governments. I have put these claims before the Senate and it is high time that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) took such comments on board and endeavoured to answer the points raised and the protests I have put forward on behalf of all the Queensland people, who are not receiving their fair share of Federal Government funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak for long. SPEECH.PARA: On the question of funding to the States over the past couple of years, one very important fact should be noted. In 1986-87, the States' general purpose payments-I am not sure whether they were called financial assistance grants then; a comparable payment, anyway-had a 2 per cent increase in real terms. One could certainly argue that in that critical 1986-87 Budget the Commonwealth should not have been so generous to the States. If that argument had been put, it would have to be counted as legitimate. However, the States received a 2 per cent increase in their general purpose payments in the 1986-87 Budget at a time when real wages, which comprised the great bulk of State government expenditure, were actually falling. It is difficult to make a judgment as to the combined effect of those two factors, but it probably meant an effective increase in real terms of about 4 per cent in that particular year. That needed to be clawed back and it has been clawed back.

Senator Stone referred to the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates of net borrowing requirements of Queensland in particular, and it is important to note that for a number of years all the States had hollow logs stuffed with money from their excess borrowings when they actually accumulated cash reserves during the permissive regime which applied in the early 1980s in the period of the so-called resources boom-which never happened. Queensland still had a very much larger cash reserve, or money stuffed in hollow logs if one prefers that term, than the other States. There was an element of judgment in that, but it would be welcomed by the Commonwealth if Queensland, or indeed all the States, made a proper disclosure of their financial assets. If they were to do that, the Commonwealth would be in a much better position to make accurate judgments than it now is. Queensland not only does not, in common with most other States, make a proper disclosure of its financial assets but, to the best of my knowledge, it still does not have even a public accounts committee-an issue on which I understand Senator Boswell expressed some sensitivity.

If clause 7 were to be activated, the Treasurer would be bound to determine what constituted the excessive borrowing in accordance with arrangements agreed with other States-in other words, to enforce the global approach resolution of the Loan Council which was accepted by all States other than Queensland and which defines in detail what constitutes a borrowing, subject to the global limits. The Acting Treasurer wrote to the Premiers recently to reassure them on that specific point, so I am informed. Clause 7 will be activated only if it has been determined that a State has deliberately or through reckless disregard breached the global limits.

The only other point I wish to make relates to the second reading amendment. The Government will, of course, oppose it. I do not intend to spend a great deal of time on it but the bald assertion that most of the 1988-89 prospective Budget surplus is based on increased taxation is simply not true. However, it puts in a nutshell the very problem that is being faced by elderly people in our country, thanks to 5 1/2 years of Labor rule. The letter is addressed to the Commissioner of Taxation in Tasmania and reads:
Dear Sir/Madam,
The INCOME TAX forms are completed as requested and enclosed herewith for your Hobart office.
As son of Mrs X, the widow for whom the taxation papers apply, I submit the following statements for your kind consideration.
My mother is 90 years old and very frail.
She has been a widow for over 20 years.

During these 20 years she has laboured at no charge and with no income to assist at the city mission and Old People's Homes etc. Throughout Launceston. (For example, sorting old clothing for the poor, etc.). Hers has been a labour of love. Where most would use a car or taxi, Mother has walked! She has NEVER owned a car. She has NEVER kept money and kind, but given it away to help the needy, unfortunate, hospitalized, disabled and thousands of people like those who mostly claim Government assistance. Mother's bank balance has always been low. Kept to the barest minimum.

Over the last few years she has tried hard to save a little cash to be able to buy a new bed, heater and paint the home and attend to a few repairs and maintenance items, including replacing a 20 year old gas stove!

Unfortunately, the increased bank interest on her savings for these repair items has put her in a tax situation. The first time in her life! How sad! The living members of Mum's family are broken hearted. What can we do? Please be gracious in this matter and these unfortunate circumstances. I know Mum appreciates the pension and thank you; but for a 90 YEAR OLD who has practically nothing and has given most of her life for helping others in the community it appears totally unjust if she should have to pay INCOME TAX!

My Mother is VERY well known throughout Tasmania and should you wish to verify any statement or seek any references, please contact the likes of CITY MISSIONS, Launceston or Hobart, Old Peoples Homes, Superintendent of Police, Church Ministers and the like.
PLEASE HELP US.
Mother does not know I'm writing, therefore please send your reply to me at the above address as any Government Correspondence may upset Mum's deteriorating health.
This letter IS NOT A COMPLAINT, but simply stating the honest truth about a 90 YEAR OLD WIDOW who serves God and her community and this gentle, kind lady happens to be my MOTHER.
Yours sincerely, Mr X

I ask the Government of this country: What has it done that it could possibly be so out of touch with the elderly and the poor, quite apart from family members, that it can allow elderly people such as Mrs X to be in this situation? She is not well off. In fact, she is very poorly off and has been all her life, as that letter reveals. Yet, thanks to this Government's direct policies and intentions, she is now in a situation where, for the first time in her life, at the age of 90 she is liable for income tax. What a callous, disgusting government. Surely it should take action in matters such as this and do something to help the elderly, who have contributed so much to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak at length in this adjournment debate. I draw to the attention of the Senate an Anzac Day address which was given by the Reverend Dr Malcolm Mackay at the 1988 Anzac Day dawn service in Canberra. I came across this address because it was sent to me by a leading Australian businessman, who was very impressed by the sentiments it contained. The copy he sent to me was published in the Mining Review of August 1988. Essentially, the address is a plea for greater unity and understanding in Australia. I think the sentiments are extremely good and ought to be considered by many Australians as they focus on the position of Aboriginal Australians. I think what Dr Mackay has to say is well worth consideration. Because we are not broadcasting and there are very few senators here to speak in the adjournment debate I do not propose to read this address. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of Dr Mackay's address.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Forging the Foundations of National Unity

As the debate about the future of Australia's Aborigines gathers pace, the Rev. Dr Malcolm Mackay looks at some past and future factors affecting their place in Australian society. Dr Mackay, a minister of the Presbyterian Church, served in the Australian Parliament from 1963 to 1972 and was Minister for the Navy in the McMahon Government from 1971 to 1972. Before joining the Federal Ministry he had been chairman of a group of oil and mineral exploration companies, while maintaining his interest in church affairs. This article is based on an address he delivered at the 1988 Anzac Day dawn service in Canberra, which was broadcast throughout Australia.
Anzac Day 1988 calls for straight thinking and bold speaking. Australia today is in peril, and we who symbolise her defence have a duty to speak.
I will not dwell on the disastrous erosion of our armed services. My theme is nearer home. The land we love is in danger of losing its integrity, its very foundations.
There are three things we need desperately today: a balanced view of the past; a willingness to change; and the guts to start with ourselves.

In this dawn hour my heart goes back to a simple grave marked by the rising sun of the First AIF. My mother lies there. She was an ANZAC. Beside her lies my father. They met at Gallipoli, 73 years ago. My mind travels to France, and I see Verdun with those acres of crosses, and the huge charnel house for the bones of the unidentifiable. More than a million young men lie there. Then across the battlefields of the Somme and beyond, the cemeteries stretch. Is there not something here we must place at the heart of our celebration in 1988? All of us?

My Aboriginal brothers and sisters-you too! Do you imagine for one moment that your ancestors could have simply gone on and on, living as they did before 1788-even if no Britishers had come to these shores? All Europe was reaching out for expansion and empire. Every Australian, new and old, should join in celebration and it was Britain which won the day. Do you believe any other European, or indeed Asian power would have made a better developer?

Coming nearer our time, had we lost World War II, had the Nazi Germany triumphed, can any of our Aboriginal or Asian friends believe that Hitler's mad dream of racial supremacy would have treated them better? Surely there is room for celebration here by all who love freedom and the rule of law.
Some argue that the cruelties of those days and the deprivation of lands held by our earliest inhabitants condemns any celebration. Fair enough. But . . .

My wife and I were recently in the far north-west of Scotland, in ancestral Mackay country. Historians describe the Mackays as direct descendants of the aboriginal inhabitants of that country. What did I find? In an area where once small farms were so numerous that a regiment of soldiers was raised there, well after 1788, there are now only lonely patches of blackened stones and a few cinders of rafters. My people, like other Highlanders and many of the Irish, were driven out of their tribal lands by bayonet, fire and brutality-long years after Cook came to Botany Bay. My point is this: it was wrong to take the moral values of the twentieth century and simply apply them to the eighteenth.

In 1788 the final rules for possessing any land were two-the capacity to defend it, and the ability to develop it. In those days there was no integrated Australian people, no national consciousness, no capacity to bring agriculture and animal husbandry and mining to the least habitable continent on earth. It is only recently, and very largely due to the British and Judao-Christian influences of the years that have intervened, that more humane values are emerging. Surely that is something every Australian ought to celebrate.
Willingness to change

Great changes are needed if we are to make this the kind of nation our Aboriginal people have a right to expect and our pioneers and our defenders have given their lives to create. But let me sound a solemn warning. The most dangerous enemies Australia faces today are those who use every good cause, every need for change as a means of dividing and polarising the nation. This is true of our environment, of education, of the status of women. And, especially in this bicentennial year, it is true of Aboriginal affairs.
There are those active destroyers in our midst whose real motivation is to exploit every grievance and sharpen every possibility of division in their lust for power.
The whole world today needs desperately to find a better way than violence and war. Sheer survival as a race depends on it.

Let me tell you a true story. A conference in Argentina recently was sponsored by a group of people with the conviction that there was no way ahead for many personal or national confrontations merely on the basis of appeals to the past, to justice or the use of force. The only victorious way was for a wiping clean of the slate-for total forgiveness.

At that conference there was the officer who had commanded the Argentinian ground forces in the Falklands war. He saw that only Almighty God could give people the guts to forgive and show them the way that this should be done. He had a most compelling thought-that he should go to Britain and seek out his opposite number in the British regiment which had carried out the counter-invasion. He obeyed that thought. In London he contacted the chaplain of the regiment, who tried in vain to arrange a meeting between the two men. Two days later, the British officer phoned to say that he felt it his duty to meet the Argentinian. When the visitor's car arrived at regimental headquarters the British officer was outside, waiting. As the Argentinian moved towards him he strode forward, and, literally in tears, they silently embraced.

There are greater forces in the world than hatred, vengence, violence, racial feuds and lust for power. We can no longer afford the luxury of reviving the past, from which both sides can easily obtain vindication for enmity. We must build a new future based on mutual respect and growing co-operation, which require costly forgiveness, and insistence on the equality of all Australians before God, the law and each other.
Start with ourselves

We should remember that many later comers to this land have also been dispossessed people . . . the convicts, the Highland Scots, the Irish farmers, the so-called captive nations of Europe, the Indo-Chinese . . . the list is great.
How do we forge the foundations of national unity?

It begins with true listening, to each other and to the still small voice of Almighty God. It is high time we made a determined attempt to listen to our friends of other cultures and races, or, as the Indians put it, ``to walk a mile in the other man's moccasins.'' That takes guts. Most of us find it easier to defend our ghettos than to reach out to our neighbour who is different. My challenge to all who have served and love Australia is to make persistent endeavours this year to bridging the race and culture gap-to listen to and really hear the other man or woman, and deep inside ourselves to heed the inner voice which for each of us is the final arbiter of right and wrong.

One last thought. This country had been the country of choice of millions of people of varied races and cultures who have decided to make their homes here. Why? Because there had been something about our way of life, our British traditions, our Christian values, our rules of law and democratic government which decided them to trust their lives and their children's lives to us. Let those who decide our future be warned. If those values and those standards are eroded and destroyed, if our roots are severed and we become an amorphous disunited mob, then we will be easy prey to the enemy within as well as to challenge from without.
It is still true that the price of freedom is eternal vigilance-matched with sacrifice-by all Australians, together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express concern at the difficulty one has in extracting information from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA), notwithstanding the recent reported suggestion that there will be a full inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission and, I assume, the Department generally. I refer to the fact that only as a result of an application under freedom of information have I been able to get a number of audits. The audits have demonstrated grave impropriety in two cases and maladministration in a third.

SPEECH.PARA: As recently as 24 October, when I made an application for a refund of the fees payable under freedom of information, I was advised by the Department that it had carefully considered the grounds cited in support of my request. However, it considered that there were insufficient public interest grounds to remit the fees and charges levied. I do not mind the $25 or $30 required to provide me with the information, but it seems to fly in the face of contentions that the Government is concerned to ensure that the finances and the management and the administration of the Department are adequate.

I remind the Senate of a speech I gave in this Parliament in respect of the Oombulgurri community, which had lost in excess of $100,000. The white bookkeeper had disappeared, either with or without the money. There were businesses in the town of Wyndham that were unable to pay their bills because they found themselves major creditors to the Oombulgurri community. As I have said, the audit demonstrated grave concern for the finances. I understood from the Department at the time we were having a Committee of the Whole discussion on Estimates that it was looking for the bookkeeper, it was looking to find out where the money was, and it was going to take appropriate action if it could find either. To my knowledge, nothing since that point has been done in respect of those matters.

I then raised the matter of the Marra Worra Worra Association. I found that there were grave irregularities with the management of its finances. It received cheques to the value of $2.6m each year in the form of what is known commonly as `chuck in'. In other words, these poor souls would get their pensions or their social welfare benefits provided to the group which then cashed it in a lump sum. On occasions there was a float of up to $100,000. The Marra Worra Worra group did not even have a safe adequate enough to put the money in. Be that as it may, a spot audit found up to $10,000 in discrepancies in the float. In fact, a test float done on 27 August 1987 revealed further errors totalling $26,239. The Corporation operated a trust account and received and disbursed income tax refund cheques on behalf of members. The books of account were not properly maintained, resulting in a shortfall of trust funds totalling $8,859 which were made good from corporation funds.

I will not bother to read again to the Senate a copy of that speech, but it is there to be read by those who have a concern for these matters. The more recent outrage is the letter from the Department when I required audited statements from the Wangkatjungka Community Inc. I have only quickly read what the auditor said about that community. On page 1 of his report he said:

The books of account generally were not maintained in a manner to enable them to be properly and conveniently audited. In the absence of detail many generalisations of income expenditures have been made in financial reports.

The community store was operated by members until November 1986 when a community store manager was employed. Prior to November store takings were not regularly banked and resulted in apparent trading losses of $8,597 as disclosed in the accounts. Subsequent to November 1986 the store has functioned at a profit. Because of the limited staff in the store internal control over sales income is not practical. However, the gross profit margin suggests that store takings are being now correctly reported.
In another paragraph the auditor says:

In my audit report of 30 June 1986 I highlighted the lack of control and records for the consumption of diesel fuel in the electricity generators. To the best of my knowledge adequate control and records are still not maintained.

What caused him to raise his eyebrows about the dieseline fuel generators for the electricity was that in the cool months when the air-conditioner was not required the consumption of diesel fuel went up. Clearly it was being stolen, not to mention the fact that wages were being paid to the operator who did not even live there. To my knowledge nothing has been done about that. I could talk about the fact that the auditor complained about private aircraft charters by a white man associated with the community to travel back and forth to Derby. I could talk about the 43 cases of beer-that is the figure I recall-put down as being for the entertainment of visiting guests. They must have had the Labor Party Caucus, for goodness sake-43 cartons to entertain guests. And so it went on. To my knowledge there has been no adequate response from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you get an invite?

—I am always very welcome at Wangkatjungka, but I have to say that whenever I get there the community is always dry. People are always saying, `We'd love to give you a drink, Senator, but we've just had the Labor Party here'.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not be deterred by the letter from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs that tells me that I should not have a refund because this is not a public interest matter. What is? There a number of communities in the north-west of Western Australia in which money is being stolen, misappropriated or mismanaged. To my knowledge nothing has been done about it. This is the third time I have raised it in the Parliament. On the information I have available to me now, what I have said so far is just the tip of the iceberg of incompetence and, I suspect, if stealing is corruption, of corruption. I intend to pursue the matter, notwithstanding the fact that the only way I can get the information is under the freedom of information legislation and that I am told to pay for it because my application is not in the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —We're all going broke paying for freedom of information.

—Absolutely, but they will go down the tube before I go broke. I have no intention of letting the matter rest. I ask the fundamental question: What is in the public interest if not the disclosure of auditors' reports that say the books are so bad that they cannot possibly be audited? So far I have only touched the edge, scratched the surface, of Marra Worra Worra, Wangkatjungka and Oombulgurri.

SPEECH.PARA: I will mention Kalumburu because I happen to be on my feet. This group, when I last checked, was technically insolvent but it had the Department examining the prospect of having its own aeroplane. One of the reasons the Oombulgurri group is bankrupt is that it charters aircraft to fly from Oombulgurri across the Cambridge Gulf to Wyndham to cart cartons of beer back and forth for them. It has an aerial taxi service. I am not saying that the Department has agreed but it has undertaken a feasibility study. One wonders why there is racism, indignation, anger and rage in the north-west of Western Australia. We should not blame the black communities or the white communities; we should blame incompetent management and bad government. If one looks at these audit reports one can see that the DAA itself has made no effort to put matters right. I just hope that next time I apply for information that reveals bad management and dishonesty in these groups the Department will be gracious enough at least to concede that it is in the public interest that such information be on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 19 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures is the Government taking to co-ordinate the control of flow of industrial effluent into Australia's waterways.

(2) What is being done to control the use and disposal of organo tin based anti-fouling paints which have been shown to be extremely toxic to estuary marine life, shellfish and other aquacultural species.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth controls the dumping of wastes, including industrial wastes, in Australian waters through the provisions of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. For dumping purposes, Australian waters extend from internationally agreed baselines outwards for 200 nautical miles. Inwards, Australian waters extend to low water mark but do not include waters within the limits of a State. However, the discharge of effluent from land-based pipelines falls outside the ambit of the Act.

The control of discharge of industrial effluent into waters within the limits of a State, or through landbased pipelines, is a State responsibility. Permits issued by State authorities to discharge waste water specify quality standards to control or prevent undesirable effects such as pollution of the adjacent coast of waters.

(2) State and Northern Territory registrars of pesticides have agreed to take steps to require registration of organotin based antifouling paints by 1 July 1989. Paints which release the active organotin constituent into the water at a rate exceeding prescribed limits will not be registered. The label of registered antifouling paints will contain instructions for safe disposal of wastes and containers. These instructions will be legally binding under State pesticides legislation.

Because the concentration of organotin in estuarine waters is highly dependent on local conditions such as boat numbers and tidal flushing, it will be necessary to continue to monitor concentrations in sensitive areas to determine whether further steps need to be taken. A number of State governments and other bodies will be undertaking this work.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the protracted and difficult negotiations undertaken by the Minister in his attempts to save the rainforests of northern Queensland from the axe, could the Minister give an overview of the latest developments in the following areas: (a) progress of negotiations dealing with suggested areas for logging and preservation; (b) any new developments with respect to legal challenges either by the Federal Government, the State Government, or logging interests either corporate or individual; (c) the level of compensation offered either to organisations or individuals to compensate them for any perceived loss of livelihood; and (d) the level of acceptance by those offered settlements by the Federal Government, or alternative job options.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The World Heritage Bureau recommended in June this year that the World Heritage Committee inscribe the Wet Tropical Rainforests of North East Australia on the World Heritage List. The Bureau also requested further information from Australia by 1 October on future management arrangements for the area, revision of the delimitation of the nominated area and some issues of land ownership and use.

There have been extensive discussions between members and officials of the Commonwealth and Queensland governments about these and related issues since the Bureau meeting. A progress report was submitted to the World Heritage Committee Secretariat at the end of September, as requested by the Bureau. The Queensland Government has been sent a copy of that Report, together with a letter proposing further discussions on the details of the nomination.

(b) The Queensland Government has continued with its December 1987 application to the High Court seeking permanent injunctions to restrain Commonwealth Government actions connected with World Heritage nomination and protection of the Wet Tropical rainforests.
(c) The Commonwealth Government has provided $75.3 million for a structural adjustment package for those affected by the cessation of rainforest logging.

Up to $50.9 million will be used over the next three years to create jobs and provide other adjustment assistance for displaced workers. Jobs will be created in reafforestation, World Heritage area management, public works and by providing seed money for private and community initiatives. Other adjustment assistance measures include a dislocation allowance, wage subsidies, retraining, relocation assistance and, for workers aged 55 years and over, an early retirement payment of up to $30,000.
Up to $24.4 million is available as compensation for companies and businesses substantially and directly affected by the cessation of commercial forestry operations in north Queensland.

(d) As at 23 September 1988, 186 workers were eligible for assistance. All have been paid the dislocation allowance, with 81 taking up offers of alternative employment, nine undertaking retraining, six being assisted with relocation and seven being given wage subsidies. The remainder of the displaced workers have either found alternative employment, have applied for the early retirement payment or have chosen not to take up any adjustment assistance.

In relation to business compensation an initial payment has been made to Hancock Bros Pty Ltd, while financial assistance is being provided to the Associated Plywood Sales mill at Ravenshoe to enable it to re-tool to process plantation timber. Compensation offers have been made to a number of other companies, while claims from other businesses are being assessed.
